title: “Good Location!”
text: We went there september 2010, stayed 10 days. This is a very good low budget hotel. If you visit New York you don't spend allot of time in your hotel, only for sleeping and showering. Quite basic but still good. Staff is very friendly, the hotel is clean. If you walk a bit upwards from the hotel,to the metrostation, you'll find an very nice mexican restaurant. Very good food!!

title: “perfect”
text:
This hotel was amazingly priced for the location and wonderful accomodations!
The room was a wonderful size for an NYC hotel. Bathroom was a great size and had a tub and not a standup shower.
Rooms were clean. Nicely decorated. Clean. Quiet. Pleasent staff.
Fabulous location!!!!

title: “Quiet, great location, and CHEAP”
text: Stayed here one Saturday night in December before Christmast. Close to the Met and Central Park! Very quiet room with no bath, but it was cheap.

title: “Clean, comfortable and great location, loved it!!”
text: We spent 5 nights in Oct 2010 and we had a clean, fresh-smelling room. We faced the front, right over the bar entrance and slept with window open and heard no noise. The staff was great, helped us open windows on the top, gave directions for using the bus to La Guardia airport and were very friendly. The location was great--lots of restaurants, grocery close by and only 4 short blocks to subway. We were close to Central Park & felt safe walking around at night. We will definitely stay at the Amsterdam Inn when we return to New York.

title: “Dank, Smelly, Depressing and with heavy early am construction to Boot”
text:
I stayed a few weeks ago, dropped my bags at the pleasant ( and very clean) reception area, and then headed out for the day. I returned early evening and found that the room they had given me was directly next to a bathroom. 
The room was dank, the carpet was soggy, the linens appeared to have been changed before my arrival, but they were stained and torn - nothing you want to see when you enter a hotel room.
Because of its proximity to the toilet, and the sewage smell coming from the bathroom, the room smelled and felt like an extension of the bathroom.
Add to the equation thin walls and drafty windows and ear splitting drilling and heavy construction that began early in the am, and you've basically got a nightmare on your hands.
After I saw the room, I immediately went back to reception to ask if they could switch my room. They said they were full. I asked if they could move me the next morning, but they said all the rooms had been assigned for the following night. (This contradicted what I was told when I arrived, that rooms were assigned to new guests by midday.) All that they offered me was air freshener that didn't even begin to help.
I have to say that the reception people were really nice, and it did look like the second floor of the hotel - where reception was - had been freshly cleaned and painted ( I did not see rooms, just the hallway). Also the location was great.
This place definitely has potential, for a basic hotel, it could be easily refreshed by simple and easy to vacuum rugs and an Ikea run, but alas..
I left as soon as construction woke me, and later called the manager who credited me about half back.
Even so, its beyond wrong to not warn travelers of construction, that will affect their stay, to say the least.
Having to find a hotel at 8pm for a last minute stay in new york is a nightmare too, something i wouldn't wish on anyone.
I did end up walking over to Hotel 17, which was the other place i was considering for my stay. I WISH i had chosen that place, set up was very similar, small rooms and shared baths down the hall, but the room they showed me was what the Amsterdam Hotel could be: clean, stylish, no frills but comfortable and a definite find for an "affordable" hotel in manhattan.

title: “I'll keep coming back.”
text:
I've stayed in the Amsterdam Inn twice in the last 5 years, and I will continue to do so until my legs can't carry me up the steps anymore. Yes, this property is a walk-up. But for the price, you will not get a better value in a good neighborhood in NYC. The rooms are clean and safe, and the staff is exceptional. I'm guessing they ask you to leave the key at the front desk because they still actually use KEYS not key cards, and they can be expensive and time consuming to replace if they are lost by guests. 
I don't understand the reviews saying mattress pads were not on mattresses and sheets were thread-bare. We had mattress pads and clean, soft, high quality sheets on both occasions my husband and I have stayed. 
The biggest reason I would recommend this hotel is the professionalism, courtesy, and integrity of the staff. My husband dropped his wallet in the room right before we checked out. TJ, the front desk attendant, called us within an hour after our leaving to let us know that the housekeeping staff had found it. With her help, we received my husband's wallet back the next day. We can't thank TJ, the housekeeping staff person, or the Amsterdam Inn enough.
So if you can stand the walk-up, a good neighborhood, clean rooms, courteous staff, and a great value, I'd highly recommend the Amsterdam Inn for your stay in NY. Central Park is only a couple blocks away, and there are tons of great restaurants and shopping in the area. It's everything we ever need for our stays there.

title: “So bad, we checked out after one night!”
text:
We booked this hotel online and arrived into Nyc on thanksgiving night. After having to carry our luggage up stairs, we checked in and were given the room right next to reception.
The room was clean, but it was not worth the 200$ per night rate. 
Due to traveling 30+ hours we were extremely jet lagged and probably got an hours worth of sleep. The room was also extremely noisy, we could hear conversations that people were having at the bar downstairs. We decided to go for a walk and around 2am and reception said we had to hand the keys in which was really weird. After having a bit of breakfast in a 24 hr diner across the road, we made our way to macys for the black Friday 
sales. 
We had made the decision to check out of the hotel in the morning.
I would give this hotel a wide birth especially if you are stay for a long period of time ( we were in Nyc for 11 days.)
The website is misleading as it states it's a boutique hotel and the pictures don't even compare to the real room.
It is probably great for backpackers, but honestly don't know if a back packer would pay 200$ per night!

title: “NIce value”
text:
The hotel is definetely a nice option if you're on a small budget and don't want to stay in an unsafe neigborhood.
I had real little expectations about the hotel, as other reviews were pretty scaring, but I decided give the hotel a chance, as it was the only non-shared bathroom hotel room in Manhattam for less than U$ 200 per night (my rate was U$ 143 per night, before taxes).
The neighborhood is nice two blocks away from the subway and 4 blocks away from the AMNH. The dakota building is even closer. Nice places to eat near the hotel and a market to buy food to use in the microwave or store in the room fridge.
The reception area is really small and the steep stairs to reach it are kinda scary when you first met. Be prepared to carry your luggage as there won't be anyone to help you. But they'll keep your luggage if you arrive too early to check in or if you're going to leave late. So, it's not big deal it being so small. Maybe the only problem is if you stay in one of the rooms just next door to the reception, it can be a little noisy as the other guests necessarily will have to call in reception for their keys. My room was on the same floor as the reception and I really had no problem.
The room itself seems brand new (despite the 80's decoration) and had a nice queen size bed, cable TV (21 inches tube), microwave, fridge, a place to rest your luggage and a chair. The bathroom is great, not big but not the smallest I've ever seen, with a really nice shower with all hot water I needed. Complimentary bath amenities were unexpected as it's a 1 star hotel.
My only complaint as that the room and the bathroom were really clean when I arrived, but was not well cleaned every day - or not cleaned at all. The rubbish was collected everyday as the towels and bed linen was changed, but there was no real cleaning during my stay. As I've stayed for only 5 nights it was not a problem, but in a longer stay I would be worried.

title: “Misleading Website; Ok for resting your head”
text:
The staff at the Amsterdam Inn were really helpful and I felt very safe in the building. It was odd that they made you leave your room key at the desk every time you left the building, but maybe they have their reasons. The rooms are super old and not at all luxurious, but for people who just want to see New York as cheaply as possible (without full-on hostel environment) this is a great place for them. We just made sure we were locking up our suitcases every time we left the building. It was a great hotel for us because we literally left at 8am every day and returned 11pm or later, just to sleep. The beds were clean and the rooms, while very very old, were sufficient. There were shared bathrooms and it seemed like the staff spaced people out so there were a few people on each floor, meaning the bathrooms weren't crowded and the floors weren't noisy. I was comfortable there after the initial shock of the room passed.
If you look at the Amsterdam Inn's website you will notice they boast "Newly renovated rooms with kitchenettes"...this was certainly not the case when we stayed there. Maybe SOME rooms have kitchenettes, but we sure didn't. It was unfortunate because we had hoped to have breakfast food at the hotel every day to minimize eating out. This hotel does not provide facecloths. You get towels, you get soap, but no facecloths. There was a sink in the bedroom which was actually really nice.
The outlet in the room (there was only one) was extremely loose so charging our phones or plugging in a curling iron was almost pointless, as they would keep flicking on and off. If you want a hairdryer here you have to LEAVE your identification at the front desk while you have the appliance. Not joking. I asked if they could just photocopy it, they said no.
The person I traveled with actually found a cockroach in their bed one night. I understand that bugs sometimes just find their way in there, but it was gross. Another night someone used the shared shower on our floor and left his underwear and towels in the washroom for HOURS. You had to climb over them to get to the toilet. When I asked the person at the front desk to have someone come up to take care of it, he said nobody works in the evenings. So basically we had to wait for that person to re-visit the bathroom and realize they left their things.
This hotel starts on the second floor of a building, and they have multiple floors, and NO elevator or escalator. So you could have to lug your things up to the 4th floor. They say wireless internet is available, so I called the front desk to order this internet service, and the guy at the desk told me I had to call a company called Natural Wireless to have it set up. It seemed ridiculous.
On our floor there were 2 showers...one in the main bathroom and one in a single shower room. The door to the shower room didn't lock.

title: “Very good for students”
text:
We enjoyed my stay in the Amsterdam Inn with my housband. We're students travelling with a budget and I think we got value for our money. The room was clean and kept clean the whole time. The size of the room was fine because we only needed it for sleep and rest. which we got (no disturbing noises). 
There were quite a lot of stairs for someone with bad knees or something but we didn't mind them even with our luggage.

title: “A Nice Little Hotel at Reasonable Cost”
text:
My partner and I spent two nights at the Amsterdam Inn during a trip to the states in July. Most hotels in New York - at least those we checked on on the internet - are way overpriced. Only to be expected in a major city. We booked a ensuite queen room and were more than happy with the size and cleanliness of the room. Yes, it is basic however if you want five star luxury it comes at a greater cost! Given that we spent both days until late exploring the city the Inn suited our purposes just fine. 
The hotel is handy for Central Park and easy walking distance from a couple of subway stations. Also, no problem catching a cab - it is New York after all!
I've noted that a couple of other reviewers have mentioned that traffic noise and passersby disturbed them - what can I say? Yes, there is a bit of noise, but personally we just accepted that we were in the 'city that never sleeps', not the country, and put up with it. That said, our room was to the side and overlooked a building site where they started work pretty early although to be fair this isn't going to be a permanent state of affairs.
All in all, we enjoyed our stay. The staff were very friendly and helpful. True, there is no lift however we were offered help to carry our luggage upstairs if required. I can honestly say we didn't have any real complaints and would stay here again.

title: “Don't stay at this place!”
text:
Together with a collegue I spend two nights in this hotel.
To be honest: it was not comfortable. We had a room at the front side of
the hotel just above the pub that is situated at the ground floor. The
amount of noise was terrible. Shouting people, loud music and a lot of
traffic. Things were really worsened by the fact that the window in
which the air-co apparatus was placed, was not properly sealed.
Moreover, we were not allowed to changs rooms... Please take account of
this before making a reservation!

title: “I would stay here again”
text:
I stayed alone at Amsterdam Inn a whole week last April and could confirm the good reviews I had read here. My room was a single with full bathroom (toilet + shower). Although modest, as I already expected, it was comfortable enough for one person and this was a good surprise. The room was cleaned every day and the towells were changed also on a daily basis. It had a TV set with not many channels (ESPN, USA, TNT and Weather Channel were some of them), but enough to entertain and keep informed a tired guest at the end of a day in New York. 
I found Amsterdam Inn a very clean and quiet hotel. The corridors floors were usually shining and only once in while I would hear the voices or steps of another guests -- and the hotel was not empty. Just out of curiosity, I checked the toilets and showers outside the rooms and found them also clean. Some reviews here mentioned the stairs. In fact, climbing the stairs may be a little hard, especially if you are carrying heavy luggage. When you arrive at the address of Amsterdam Inn, you have to ring a bell. The recepcionist opens the front door remotely and then you have to climb a fairly steep flight of stairs. You get to the front desk and, depending on the number of your room, maybe you'll have to climb one or two more flights of stairs. The latter was my case: I stayed in the fourth floor. Was that a problem? Not at all. My luggage was realy heavy only when I checked out, as I had bought lots of books. By then, I had a little trouble to carry the suitcase, but it was something far from unattainable.
I have only compliments to the staff. They were attentive and helped me when I had to solve a problem back in my hometown, in Brazil. They were very patient too trying to understand me when I spoke my broken English. 
The hotel provides the guest every day a voucher, which entitles its holder to have a cup of coffee (or juice) and a bagel with white cheese or butter (or jelly? I forgot what the second option was) in a coffe shop one block away. I found this great, since I´m not used to really have a breakfast. Usually, I have only a cup of coffee in the morning. So, it was a great deal for me to have for free a cup of coffee and a bagel, which was very tasty, by the way. Those vouchers saved me some precious dollars.
The Amsterdam Inn location is great. It´s a few blocks away from some city atractions, like Central Park, American Museum of Natural History, Lincoln Center, Riverside Park etc. There are at least two subway stations nearby. It´s also a great neighborhood, with good and cheap places to eat, like Artie's, at Broadway (where you can also find Zarbar´s), good bookshops and beautiful residencial buildings. For those people who really like to walk, like myself, the hotel is at a walking distance from some other interesting places, like Columbus Circle (where you find a Whole Foods store), Apple Store and so on. I found the neighborhood quite safe. Many times I returned to the hotel late at night and saw nothing suspicious. 
Finally, I paid an average rate of US$ 109 per night. It was my first time in New York. I loved the city and I am highly satisfied with Amsterdam Inn. 
PS.: Two more informations that may be useful for another travellers.
From JFK Airport to Amsterdam Inn, I got a van from SuperShuttle. The trip costed US$ 21 (US$ 19 + US$ 2 driver´s tip). It took a little longer than a cab would, I guess (one hour and 15 minutes, it was raining and the traffic was heavy), but I have no complaints. I was the second passenger to be dropped off at the hotel. When I left New York, I flew to Orlando early in the morning. To avoid any problems, I hired a private car with driver from a transportation service recommended by the Amsterdam Inn front desk. I paid US$ 40 from the hotel to La Guardia Airport. The trip took about 30 minutes.

title: “Great Place, The Amsterdam Inn”
text: I stayed at the Amsterdam Inn during the easter day weekend. I booked a clean bed with a private bathroom. I got it at a great price of $109.00 plus tax. I was very pleased with the cleansliness of the hotel. My room was serviced daily. The staff was very helpful and pleasent. The stairs could be a stretch but it's typical for N.Y.C. The location is amazing, you can't beat it, you're two blocks away from central park and one block away from Broadway. The area is very active day and night , which made me feel more comfortable coming and going. I would recommend the Amsterdam Inn to anyone who want's to pay a cheap price for a good value.

title: “Be Careful”
text:
I stayed at this hotel on my return visit to NY. In hindsight I should have stayed with the hotel I used outbound. 
Firstly there are no safes in the rooms and the staff are lightfingered. I had $1,000 worth of camera equipment taken from a closed suitcase. They request you leave your key with reception when you go out, somthing the NYPD told me not to do. When I approached reception about the missing items, the single person on reception didn't even respond, simply picked up the phone and spoke in another language. When he put the phone down he told me there was nothing he could do and that I should leave a statement. I told him I was contacting the police, he then shrugged his shoulders and told me there was nothing they could do. The manager had left, and when I asked the receptionist to raise her on the phone, she told me the housekeeping staff had left for the day and there was nothing she could do. I then called the police who took a statement and recommended I find a better hotel to stay in. What made me angry was that the staff seemed disinterested. Given that the person needed time to go through my suitcase, and my room was two doors from reception, it was obviously (as the police confirmed) an inside job. 
I had previously stayed at the Buckingham hotel and would suggest that as a better alternative.

title: “Good value”
text: I stayed in a queen room with bathroom. No complaints. Staff consistently friendly and helpful. Initial impression very poor: the entrance is swathed in scaffolding. One is buzzed into a dingy, smelly vestibule with a narrow, wooden staircase going up one storey. I thought "Oh no!" But, upon ascending the stairs I was pleasantly surprised. A building across the road is being torn down but I did not find the noise level a problem. About ten blocks to Lincoln Centre and four blocks to Zabar's. The Inn should drop their price a bit and skip the "free breakfast" which consists in coffee or juice and a bagel, served in a decidedly downmarket shop about a block away. Unfortunately, they don't have safety deposit boxes or valuables check. One has to buy in to a wireless initernet service.

title: “Cheap and Cheerful”
text: My husband and I booked into the Amsterdam Inn as he was taking part in the New York Marathon. This hotel was choosen for its location to the finish of the marathon. We found the hotel in a very pleasant quiet residual area, very close to all the sights. We both enjoyed our stay at this hotel - the room cleaned daily and fresh towels whenever needed. At the end of the day you dont go to New York to spent all day in a hotel room and the price is important and the voucher for breakfast an added bonus. A lift would have been welcome.

title: “Great choice in NYC, the Amsterdam Inn”
text:
My boyfriend and I booked a week at the Amsterdam Inn early September this year. After reviewing other hotels in NYC that one seemed like a good choice for the value. We booked a double bedroom with bathroom share.
At arrival, the guy at the reception was very nice. The room was not big but just the good size and very clean. You have TV, two big mirrors and a sink. The toilets/ bathroom on the same floor were also very clean. They remained clean for the rest of the week, which shows that the cleaners were doing a great job all day long.And you never have to wait to go to the loo or the shower room.Our bed was done everyday and the towels changed daily as well. The hotel informed us before booking that some building work was currently taking place and it would start at 7am.
To be honest, yes there was noise, but that didnt stop us from sleeping properly, even until 10am one morning.
The hotel location is ideal. The upper west side is very calm and a nice neighbourhood. Three subway stops are available around the hotel within 10 min walk. The area offers a great choice of restaurants and diners for the breakfast. And the icing on the cake, there is a pub below the hotel where you can go back in the evening to have a nice diner for a reasonable price rather than wondering where to eat in this huge town.
At the reception, the guys were always smiling and ready to help.
So really, i would defenitely recommend this hotel to anyone who is looking to spend some time discovering NYC, and doesnt want to spend hundreds in a hotel where you will only a few hours per day, but dont want to end up in a nasty B&B either!
Go on their website to have a look, they also have two other hotels situated downtown!

title: “Loved the more-than-adequate Amsterdam Inn”
text:
Fellow reviewers, you misled me. From the previous reviews, we were wondering if we'd made a mistake by booking with no research, but the price was great ($109/night on a weekend, booked the day of), and I have fond memories of hostel-hopping at many like places in Europe. From the complaints ranging from dirty rooms to rude staff, my expectations were low. We were so pleasantly surprised that I feel like I should give five stars! The staff was delightful and helpful, the room was completely clean, the bathroom was newly renovated with tile everywhere, there was a clean and sparkly sink in our room (which was 310, a full with shared bath), the sheets were clean and smelled good, and lo and behold, we had air conditioning, contrary to several reviews. We even had a TV! If you're the type who would rather spend money on a great restaurant than on a hotel room where you'll spend 8 hours, tops, then this is a good option. Be flexible about the stairs and imagine that you have an ideally located studio apartment in the greatest city in the country. If the Hyatt is more your speed and you tend to find lots to complain about, try another hotel. 
Not all rooms have the free breakfast voucher, so ask upon booking. The deposit is a refundable $10.

title: “Pay the extra money & go somewhere else!!!!”
text: My partner and I stayed at the Amsterdam Inn for 3 nights in May 2008. We paid $130 per night (including tax) for a Double Room with Shared facilties. This was the cheapest accommodation in New York we could find. As soon as we got there we wished we had payed the extra $20 and gone somewhere else. The only good thing about this place is the location. It is centrally located, near transport & only a couple blocks away from Central Park. The room was tiny & not overly clean. The room had a tiny bed, a tiny rack to hang your clothes on, a small basin & a chest of drawers. It was stuffy but we couldn't open the tiny window because right next to our room was a massive construction site that continued to be noisy every morning from 6am to 7pm. There were 2 toilets & 2 showers on our floor, one of which was so small you couldn't even sit down properly because the door would hit your knees. It was also not the cleanest. Breakfast was not included & there was no Internet. The stairs were steep & the staff at reception are rude. They were too busy talking on the phone to serve. If you want to store your bags, there is no safely locked room, you just have to put it behind the front desk with the staff. We would not stay here again, nor would we recommend this place to anyone. You will be better off paying an extra $20 a night & going somewhere else.

title: “OK if your on a tight budget”
text:
We stayed at the Amsterdam Inn for one night, we chose it because it was the cheapest we could find for that night and all the other hotels were very expensive. The main problem with this hotel is that there is no lift, we had to carry our two large cases up three flights of very steep stairs, but we did get some help from a member of staff. 
The hotel room was generally clean as was the shared bathroom. The room was very very small and it was a struggle to open our suitcase because of the lack of space. Overall the hotel was fine for us as we only stayed for one night and were looking for some where cheap.

title: “Don't stay here unless you really can't find somewhere else”
text: Admittedly this hotel is on the cheap side for New York, but I wish we had forked out a bit more. It adjoins a large building site and the noise was inescapeable, add the clanking of the ancient (but very necessary) air conditioning and it was impossible to sleep. Breakfast was supposedly included, but it amounted to a voucher for a dirty bagel bar just up the road, that gave you a bagel and a drink with nowhere decent to sit and eat it.

title: “The Amsterdam Inn gets our vote!”
text:
We spent 4 nights at the Amsterdam Inn in July. This was our first trip to NYC, and not wanting to pay the price of most hotels, I relied on Tripadvisor and other travel sites to research other options. I was looking for basic, clean, with private bathroom facilites.
The Amsterdam Inn met these and more. I must point out, we were on the first floor, in a "deluxe queen", so I can't speak for the upper floors (no elevator, and some shared bathrooms). We were very satisfied, and paid from $100 to $200 less per day than the average New York hotel rate. Restaurants are numerous, many are inexpensive, the subway staion is 3 blocks away, the buses run on Amsterdam Ave., it is 2 blocks to Central Park. The staff was friendly and helpful. Negatives: the one window looked out onto the construction of a new building and eventually will look at the wall, and also the bed sheets were thin.
We travel quite a bit, and normally stay in chain hotels like Quality Inn, Holiday Inn Express, etc. This was very comparable, and I recommend the Amsterdam to anyone not demanding luxury.

title: “Only for those on a VERY tight budget!”
text: Stayed at the Amsterdam for 3 nights. Although it was not a disaster, I would not stay here again. It is for those on a very limited budget only. It has no charm or warmth. Because of the construction the corner is dusty and noisy. The actual construction noise was not that bad in the morning, although our room did not face the site. There are a lot of stairs and carrying your luggage can be a problem. (Although they did ask if we needed help when we checked in.) The check in desk is located one flight up from the street. The staff, although not nasty, are not very welcoming or friendly. The room was very tiny. There is the bed, sink, and dresser. Even an extra chair would have been nice, although I guess it wouldn't fit. The bed barely accomodated my husband and me and we are not very large people. It was not easy to sleep as the bed was pushed up against the wall. If you are tall or need extra room, forget it. The carpet was worn and didn't seem too clean. Be sure to bring flip-flops! To me, a smell permeated the room like air freshener covering up old smoke. The shower/bathroom was down the hall and smelled of bleach so I guess it was clean. We have stayed at The Bellclaire which is in the same neighborhood and also has shared bath rooms. I would definitely pay the extra to stay there or try another hotel next time.

title: “A nothing special hotel”
text:
Stayed in The Amsterdam Inn for a week. Eventually we got used to the noise of the contractors next door who have been building a condo for the last year.
The accommodation is very basic but with good TV stations and decent showering facilities.
The staff were friendly but woke us up several times wanting to clean the room.
I think I would wait until the work had been finished before I stayed again

title: “Pay the extra and go somewhere else.”
text: This hotel sounded great - a boutique hotel, European feel - well forget it! I did not feel safe here, it felt like a half-way house. I skeeved everything! If you know what skeeved means you won't want to stay here. To top it off my credit card info was stolen and this is the only place I used that credit card. Not worth it.

title: “Mixed feelings about this place...”
text:
It is with mixed feeling that I have to give this place a negative review overall.
My son and I travelled to the USA in April of 2008 (holiday of a lifetime so far for me) starting in LA then to SF across to Boston then down to Martha's Vineyard and finishing in NYC at the Amsterdam before heading back home to Australia. This hotel was the worst we stayed at during our 3 weeks. But I need to qualify a few things.
NEGATIVES:
There is massive construction still taking place next door and it will continue for some time. Construction work starts exactly at 7.00am however, the workers turn up much earlier and start making a LOT of noise. The Amsterdam is literally about 3 feet away from the construction. It is very, very noisy during the week because of this. Trust me on this!!! But, to be fair, there is construction taking place all over NYC.
Rooms are very small and the sheets and blankets are thin. No elevator, tables, chairs, air-conditioning or coffee making facilities.
No elevators at all so you must haul your luggage up at least one fight of steep stairs
POSSITIVES:
Location. Everything and I mean everything is just a few blocks away. Subway, diner, grocery store, laundromat, tons of other places to eat, Central Park, bar, museum, Broadway, drug-store and on and on and on.
Bathroom was very clean and the cleaning staff were efficient and approachable.
I found all the staff friendly and helpful. If you have had negative experiences, then maybe it was your approach.
CONCLUSION: I would not stay here again UNTIL the construction work is finished. This is a very noisy place currently. Then again, you do not travel to NYC for peace and quiet. If you are not spending much time in your room (and who wants to?) then this place is okay. All the above aside we had a fantastic time in NYC and I would do it again tomorrow if I could.

title: “Not Bad for the Price”
text: Stayed there one night, in the cheapest room in the place. The hotel is exceedingly clean for what you'd expect from a budget hotel. Being in the cheapest room, I had had to share bathrooms, which were plentiful and also very clean. The TV worked fine, with about 20 cable channels. Now, there is one drawback, and is one that will abate eventually: There is a construction project adjacent to the hotel, and the workers start moving about at 6:30 a.m. They don't start the banging of hammers until 7 a.m., so until the building project is completed, this will be a problem for late sleepers.

title: “Nightmare, but ADVENTURE”
text: My friend and I didn't know what to expect when we went to the Amsterdam Inn. If it's your first time in New York, you won't care about the hotel because you'll be so excited and so busy. But when we got there, we had to hike up the dangerously steep steps, get our key and hike another 4 floors. Once we got up there we noticed there were public washrooms and bathrooms. We paniced but once we got into our TINY room, we realized we had a bathroom of our own. We had one bed, with cigarette holes etc... in the sheets. We thought we were getting two double beds but we only got the one with a huge dip in the middle. The room was super small. No extra pillows, just the one that they gave us, so when we asked the front desk they gave us an extra blanket. But honestly it was an adventure and an experience. It wasn't unbearable, just humorus. The location is pretty awesome though. You can get to central park, just down the road or hop on broadway and walk anywhere!!!

title: “Decent accomodation for the price”
text: The Amsterdam Inn is a great bargain for people looking to stay on the Upper West Side. The rooms are tiny, but comfortable. This is a great place for people who come to NYC to experience the city and only need a place to sleep after a long day of being out and about. The hotel looks a little sketchy from the outside, but the inside is pretty clean and well lit. My only complaint is that we could only get scalding water out of our shower. We were only there for 1 night so it was no big deal, but it was a little annoying.

title: “Clean and Quirky”
text:
The Amsterdam Inn has all the character of its upper-West-Side neighborhood and the location, near the Natural History museum, is ideal for exploring Central Park. Subway access is within two blocks, making all of Manhattan easily accessible. The rooms are reasonably sized for a budget hotel and everything was very clean. 
But there are a few shortcomings: 1. There is no control over the heat and when it comes on you'll be throwing the windows open, even in the middle of February. This brings us to . . . 2. The street outside and the bar downstairs can be very noisy 'til late at night 3. There is no air conditioning in the rooms. 4. There is no elevator and the stairs are very narrow. 5. Staff professionalism is inconsistent - some of the folks at the Amsterdam Inn are very helpful and friendly, others seem rather moody and aloof, or don't follow up when they say they will. 
Still, if you're on a tight budget, it's not easy to find a better bargain in New York City than the Amsterdam.

title: “Beware: Building Site Next Door”
text:
This hotel was such a disappointment. 
The Amsterdam Inn is part of a boutique(?) group called NYInns which have 3 small hotels throughout Manhattan, one in Murray Hill, one in Union Square and this one on Amsterdam Avenue. 
I had been to NYC in February 06 and stayed at the Murray Hill Inn, which at that time, I found to be a great low budget option. So naturally, when I returned to NYC in November 07, I decided to stay in Murray Hill Inn again which also proved to be a big dissappointment (see my Murray Hill Inn review). I briefly left NYC and returned to stay at the Amsterdam Inn as the Murray Hill was booked out (all bookings in November for both hotels were done in advance being too late notice to change hotels without incurring huge cost).
To my horror - the hotel is currently balancing precariously on the edge of a massive construction site next door. I suggested to the receptionist that there should be a warning on the website about the fact that there is a construction site next door, to which he responded, "there is!". I said, "there isn't, otherwise I wouldn't have booked!". As of today (31st December 2007) there still isn't! There is however, an A4 sheet paper sign at reception advising guests of the construction site. Gee whiz, how considerate.
As the property was constantly overheated (about 85F (30C)) due to the archaic Manhattan steam heating system, we needed to crack a window open in order to bring the temperature down to a more livable level - rather than the desert-like conditions we were experiencing in the room. Lucky for us (sarcasm), we were on the side of the building next to the building site. So there was no need for an alarm clock and bang on 7am the construction workers started hammering away. I had anticipated this, and requested a change of room the night before to which I was told they were booked out and there was nothing available. To add insult to injury, the sheets were so worn that they were practically transparent, the bed squeeked when ever you made the slightest movement (same problem at Murray Hill Inn) and the showers barely broke the luke warm barrier. All in all, one of the worst hotel experiences to date.
I understand it is not the hotel's problem that there is a construction site next door, however I do expect that they have a responsibility to inform their potential guests when they are making a booking. I suspect their reason for not doing this is the loss of business, however they could offer cheaper rates to encourage people to stay. 
Anyway, on complaining to the hotel in writing they offered me a reduction from the $173 I paid for the privlidge to stay in the hotel to $99. What a joke. I won't ever stay in this hotel again, nor any of the other NYC Inns. They really need to take a look at themselves. Despite the fact they position themselves as budget botique hotel - this should mean compromising basic amenities such as hot water, sheets in good condition, a quiet bed and some degree of climate control.
I would strongly suggest people consider staying elsewhere - at the very least for the time being.
Max

title: “A New York City Bargain”
text: This is not a hotel for everyone. However, if you have a sense of adventure and are looking for basic accommodations, the Amsterdam Inn may be for you. My wife and I stayed here for the 2007 New York City Marathon (November 1-4). We were pleasantly surprised. The hotel’s location at 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue is very central for midtown activities and also only two blocks from where the Marathon ends. We found the Amsterdam Inn to be secure, with a buzzer at the entrance and also at the second floor landing. An attendant is at the reception desk 24/7. The room was clean and the bed comfortable. Breakfast is included (at a coffee shop a block away). High speed internet is available (at extra cost). There is no elevator and yes, the stairs are steep. For New York City, the room rate cannot be beat ($159 weekdays, $179 weekend days). We enjoyed our stay and will return.

title: “Good for the price”
text: The Amsterdam was a pleasant surprise. It is very clean. The staff very helpful and will assist with luggage. I had a full bed with shared bath and the room was average sized.The bathroom was large and clean; in addition there was a separate small shower and toilet on the same floor. The only incident I had was with other occupants not cleaning up after themselves. When you share communal space it is common courtesy to try and clean up or at least tell the staff what needs cleaning. Otherwise the location is perfect, i rode the bus all the way down to Macy's in 25minutes. Just ask the staff how to get where you want to go.

title: “Excellent hotel, great price”
text:
My girlfriend and I stayed at this hotel for a wedding over in Long Island, and I was very impressed. First impression is that our room was extremely small, but this was expected. Surprisingly, the room and bathroom were both spotless and looked like they had recently been remodeled. I was actually really impressed with the bathroom and the shower, it was nicer and "fancier" than any chain hotel I've stayed in. The price we paid (a little under $200) was excellent for the area. The room was quiet with little city noise coming it, but I'm sure this depends on where your window is. The hotel itself is really quaint and you get the New York City living experience due to its size (small) and location.
The staff at the hotel was great as well, and the two employees we interacted with were helpful when needed but otherwise stayed out of the way. I definitely recommend the Amsterdam if you're just one or two people and don't mind a very small room.

title: “ok place, great location”
text: At first we weren't very happy. Huge construction project going on outside and very tiny, not terribly nice rooms, tiny bathrooms down the hall, steep steps, no elevator, a little creepy. However it was very clean and an absolutly wonderful location.

title: “Are you kidding me?”
text:
Are you people kidding me??? This place was horrible. Yes, it was in a good location, but that does not make up for the thread bare sheets, the horrible squeaky bed, the cheap [--] towels, and the remote control that may or may not have been used previously as a sex toy.
Um yeah, and the construction/drilling that started at precisely 7am is just one more reason why the Amsterdam Inn is off my list of places to stay in NYC. GAG. 
(We also were not given a crib for our baby. And the stairs were brutal.)
And just because their website says they are a "boutique hotel", they are not. Take my word for it.

title: “Cute, clean and central”
text: Wow, what a great little hotel. We have been travelling in the USA for six weeks and stayed at upwards of 20 different hotels and this one rates in our top five! We were lucky to get a lobby floor room because we only had one flight of stairs to climb. Our room was cozy and very clean and not too small. The front desk staff were helpful and friendly. The hotel is close to everything and in a pretty safe part of town, we always felt comfortable walking around - and for two country folks from New Zealand, that's saying something. Close to subway, the park, 5th ave and a gorgeous cafe around the corner called Cosi will killer sandwiches! We will be staying at this hotel when we return to NYC that's for sure for the price (cheap for the city) it can't be beat!

title: “Comfortable and Welcoming”
text:
Initially we were a bit nervous at pulling up in a taxi at the little door, but once we were settled in, the receptionist was fantastic. We were actually given a choice of which room we wanted! I read previous reviews that staff were negative, but we never got that vibe! They were friendly, helpful, and accomodating. The hotel is next to several great restaurants and delis and very close to the subway.
Highly recommend.

title: “Perfect location for the price!”
text: This hotel's location is perfect and incredible for the price! Subway a few minutes away, besides Central Park, very nice streets with lots of little café and restaurants. No there is no elevators, it is very small and not really made to help you relax, and it's not a hotel to stay for many nights or if you plan on staying in your room a lot... I recommend it for young travelers, couples, not sure for older people or families... but if you need a place to sleep and be in the center of NY and all the action, this is a very good place for the price. NOTE : if you get a special rate from a website, make sure to bring your sheet with the rate, as I had lost it and they charged me more than I was guaranteed!

title: “Worth Every Penny”
text: I called up American Express Concierge and asked them to recommend a hotel to stay at in NYC. I told them i wanted to be uptown. This hotel was exactly what i was looking for and in my price range. The Staff was super friendly and the rooms were much nicer than what i was expecting. I would recommend this hotel to anyone who is looking for a budget hotel with nice accomodations.

title: “The Worst Room Ever!!!!”
text:
Since our stay in April 2007 (one week!!) I tried to forget about this place!! Now let's honestly see all of it: our credit-card debit said 570 EUROS for 7 nights in a double room - i.e. 80 EUROS per night. So that's suuuper-budget for a hotel in N.Y.
B U T ......their web-site showed all those photos (which I also see here in the tripadvisors-photos...kind of room no. 401!!)
So I thought that the difference in price would be for the sharing/not sharing of the bathroom, while having the same room-standard, and so I opted for shared bathroom/no breakfast voucher.
MAN! After 15 hours of travelling, me (38 years - not 3 years!!) and my husband finally arrived and I had a 30 minutes of desperate crying!!! I carefully chose that place and it surely had nothing to do with the photos I saw!!!!
YES - that was David Lynch (beware of room 309). 
Shabby, horrible, dirty, filthy, MINI,depressing.
Moreover I am sure it was a single room, as one of us had to sit on the bed while the other was moving in the room!!!!)
That night we went out to stroll on the streets - though really tired - but I could not imagine to go back to that room (and kept on thinking of the endless 7 nights I had to stay there).
We immediately asked for a better room by paying the difference - but there was none free.
We paid 100 USD per night while the better ones seemed to be 140 USD (which I know now). The German couple next to us also had to share the bathroom BUT their room was at least the double of ours with nice furniture....it seemed as they were staying in another hotel .....!!
Being a budget-traveller most of the times - I really know what to expect (I travelled super-budget in London hostels and was really O.K. with it!!) but this time I really felt "kicked in the ass". 
WELL - New York made up for it - we hardly ever spent time in our room and we liked the zone because it seemed "real" N.Y.

title: “clean, good location”
text: Stayed at the Amsterdam Inn the weekend of May 19 in a double with private bath for $163. The hotel is very clean, staff helpful. I loved the Upper West side location. Subway was just 3 blocks away. Beware of 2 things: heavy construction is going on right next door during the day (not a problem for me since I was up by 7 am) and you'll need to go up at least 2 flights of stairs to get to the rooms.

title: “A very shabby hotel in a great location.”
text: After the general location, the best thing about the place was that the personnel were very friendly. The room itself was terrible -- very small, shabby, with an overwhelming smell of cigarettes mixed with cleaning fluid. The bed was very uncomfortable. And worst of all, the building next door was in the midst of being razed -- with the jack hammers and bull dozers starting work at 6:30am! At least the bagel at the bagel shop up the street was great!

title: “top class budget hotel!!!”
text: Queen deluxe room was great.. Clean and cozy , and bathroom was especially clean and nice! Nothing bad to say! Friendly service, excellent location.. It was nice that the breakfast in a nearby bagelstore was included. Definitely going to stay there again.. Excellent value for the money to say the least!!

title: “Budget price, budget hotel”
text:
New York is an expensive city for hotels and I chose to stay at the Amsterdam Inn to try to same some cash. You can't expect much in NY for $139 a night, and the hotel lived up to that reputation.
First of all, if you have lots of luggage or trouble climbing stairs, I would stay away from the Amsterdam Inn. 4 floors of stairs only. I was on the top floor in a 'Double bed room' with a private bath. Many of the rooms here have shared shower facilities.
The room itself was clean, but very basic. Old beds, terribly uncomfortable pillows. Surprisingly, the bathroom looked like it had been somewhat renovated. Bathroom facilities were fine.
There is quite a lot of noise from outside traffic and the windows are not double glazed, so it can be a challenge to sleep. Also, there is a lot of construction going on in the lot directly next to the hotel, so that adds to the noise.
Staff were friendly and the included breakfast at the cafe up the road was basic but ok.
Overall, if you're looking for a place to sleep with only the basics, the Amsterdam Inn is ok, but don't expect too much or else you will be disappointed.

title: “Just what we needed”
text: After reading some reviews we weren't sure what we would find but the Amsterdam Inn was just what we required it was nice, clean, friendly and cheap . I also felt safe as you had to be buzzed up to the hotel and then again to the second floor. The accomodation was very basic but then we didn't actually spend much time in the hotel - apart from sleeping, there was just so much to do. The location is good - maybe a little far out for some of the places we wanted to go but if I was on a budget I would stay here again. Central Park is close and a nice walk through the Park soon gets you to the start of the shopping on 5th Avenue. We had a twin room with en suite shower which was lovely, I'm not sure how much less the shared bathroom is but that looked clean and tidy as well ( our room was opposite). The breakfast voucher was good - choices of bagels and pastrys, we felt like proper New Yorkers. There are also lovely diners which offer some great breakfasts. The only problem we had was when we arrived at the airport and getting a taxi. Coming from the airport the taxis have a flat rate of $45 plus toll to anywhere in manhattan - we had a guy pounce on us to tell us that the taxis were metered and it would cost us $160 and he could get us there for $78. We also ordered the car service from the hotel which was OK - I didn't feel particuarly safe when we were going down some side streets (I've read too many horrors!). We got to the airport in rapid time - I think it was just my overactive imagination. I would recommend this hotel to any people who are just looking for a place to stay and not too many luxuries.

title: “European spirit”
text: I love Amsterdam because of the specific atmosphere it has and its fantastic citizens and that's why I choose the Amsterdam Hotel for my visit to New York. After I got into the hotel I thought "New Yorkers are great people!" as the receptionist and everyone was friendly. If you go to the big apple for sightseeing, this is your place--the hotel is really close to the Central Park, Soho, Chinatown, Little Italy, actually, you have it all. If you're smart traveled, you will select this hotel. The prices are competitive and the service is great. I haven't ordered breakfast (extra payment) but being in the heart of the city is not a problem to find a good place for a snack.

title: “The David Lynch Special”
text:
This place grew on me over the four days we stayed here (but it might have been Stockholm Syndrome). The room and bathroom were clean but a bit shabby. The problem was that the room had defective heating: it was about 85 degrees the entire time. The management said we might have a problem with the heat but we could open the window. They did not seem inclined to do anything at all about it and treated it like a natural disaster that was beyond their control. We did open the window but that provided a security problem and brought in huge amounts of noise from Amsterdam Street just below us. I'm not terribly familiar with steam/radiator styles of heating but the radiator was as hot as an iron turned on high and the curtains touched it. This made me very nervous. 
Otherwise, the stairs did NOT smell like urine as a previous entry suggested although if they were any steeper you would need crampons and a guide wire to get up them. The beds were comfortable and the other guests were very nice and quiet. 
The noise from the bar directly beneath the hotel and from the street was continuous and loud. 
This place is unique and "colorful" -- it would make a great place to film a David Lynch movie.

title: “Could have been better...”
text:
Myself and a friend stayed here in Nov 05. We booked directly to stay at the Murray Hill Inn. Upon arrival, they had no record of our booking even though I had printed copies of several emails from them confirming the reservation. We had even phoned three days previously and they confirmed it. They had no rooms available so moved us to their sister hotel the Union Sqaure Inn. We got there and they offered us a double room with no ensuite. I turned this down as we had booked a twin ensuite. They then moved us to another hotel, The Amsterdam Inn. After some argument they agreed to refund us the taxi fares between the hotels. 
I was not happy about staying at the Amsterdam as it was much further uptown than we had planned. When we arrived we were faced with a very very steep set of stairs which we managed to struggle up. When we got to reception I was pleasantly surprised by the very welcoming young lady on reception who apologised profusely and helped us to our room. 
It was on the first floor beside reception and was a twin ensuite. It was very clean, quite spacious and the bathroom was very modern and big. The room was facing the road and there is a fire station just around the corner so fire trucks were passing with sirens blaring several times a night. Thankfully we are both heavy sleepers!
The housekeeping staff were excellent. Fresh towels every day and our sheets were changed several times during the week. We are two very messy young girls and each evening when we came back they had lined up our shoes and put our clothes on the backs of the chairs!! Toiletries were kept well stocked and we didn't have to ask for anything. 
We met three different receptionists there on our stay and they were all pleasant, friendly and helpful. I couldn't say a bad word about them. On our departure day, we checked out that morning but we had an evening flight so they kept our bags for us and booked us a place on the mini bus to JFK. 
Also, the vouchers for breakfast were great. The bagels were yummy. I wouldn't stay here again because of all the hassle with the reservation but by the end of the stay I was much happier than I had been at the beginning.

title: “A good budget place in New York”
text:
The Amsterdam Inn is a quite pleasant clean, little place in an excellent location on the Upper West Side.
Considering the prices for a hotel room in New York, we consider it a real bargain although don't expect the Ritz.
On the Plus side:
1) Great location close to public transportation ( 1 and 9 lines as well as B and C lines)
2) Pleasant staff who do their best to accommodate your needs. TJ was especially helpful in trying to find us a room with a refrigerator and a longer bed.
3) Price (about $130 a night for a bathroom with shower) is terrific for New York at around the holiday time, which is when we went.
4) Clean -- i.e. not roach infested like other places we've been (!!!) with decent furniture and a TV.
On the minus side:
1) It's in an old tenement building, so it looks forbidding and there is no elevator. YOu must walk up all the steep steps -- probbly not good for older folks though we felt we were just burning off calories!
2) Small -- we stayed in Room 401 (larger with a nicer queen bed) and Room 304 for the last night (small with a bath, but only full sized bed) and there's not a lot of lounging room -- not that you're paying for lounging room. In room 401 you will not be able to simultaneously sit on the toilet and close the bathroom door if you're over 5'5".
3) Occasionally noisy as you can hear other hotel guests in the hallways. No traffic noise in our rooms though.
Altogether a perfectly nice place to stay as long as you understand that it's budget. But I would recommend it for anyone who just wants a clean place to stay for not much money in New York.

title: “Nice and clean room”
text: I was quite impressed with the cleanliness of the bedroom and bathrooms. The bedroom was very small but it was clean and not too bad for the price. Initially I was worried about having to queue up for the bathrooms but my concern proved unfounded since they were seldom occupied. The location was great too. The 72nd Street Subway station was around 5 mins walk. The express train to Times Square at 42nd took less than 10 mins. The area was pretty safe even at night. The downside was the steep staircase. However, you could get the staff to help you carry your luggage, which I did. The staff might not be extremely friendly but at least they were helpful and efficient. Overall, it was a good experience and I would recommend this to others who want to travel on a budget.

title: “Good location”
text: and was a real experience. Incredibly steep entry stairs followed by a four story walk-up to a sparse room, no glass to drink from, no waste basket, no closet and a feeling of no security from the fragile door. First thing I did was buy a bike chain to secure doors of the metal based sink. Sheets so thin that a paper could be read under them, blanket the same. Tattered and torn venetian blinds.. Share bath and shower that had lukewarm water but was reasonably clean. The in room microwave had yesterdays vomit inside, the refregerator had been unplugged with food debris inside, moldy and stinky. Had I not prepaid for 5 nights I wold have left and taken chances on sleeping in Central Park. An experience to be told but not to be lived.

title: “How can you not like this hostel?”
text:
I was kind of worried to book this hostel, because some comments mentioned it was shabby & rundown. However, I wasn't willing to pay over 250 dollars per night for a 8-night stay, so I decided to have a go with this hostel, which cost me 109 dollars per night. And worth (almost) every single penny, I think.
Let me start by saying our room was just like any normal hotel/motel room I ever slept in during my extended holidays in The States. King size bed, airco (noisy but sufficient), lots of closet space, mirrors, a tv, a fridge and a microwave. The bathroom is smallish, but nice: great shower!
We got clean, thick towels every day, and our beds were made with clean sheets as well. As an European I didn't have a clue about the tipping; we left the (friendly) housemaids/men 2 dollars each day. Hope I didn't offend them.
I'd never book one of the dorm rooms, because they seemed very small; the shared showers were just big enough to step into, not to turn around in once you're in there. But then, I'm probably not used to these kind of amenities anymore, and they were (like everything) absolutely clean, when we took a look around the hostel. I'm just not a very poor student anymore (lucky me).
The hostel itself is hostel-ish: flight of stairs straight from the street (camera/doorbell), a tired receptionist (the black guy and the white weird hair guy at night really friendly, sort-of-chief TJ wasn't) and a flickering tv in the background. 
Some posters here mentioned "the noise", but I honestly must say that the only noise I heard sometimes was coming from Amsterdam Avenue, where our room was looking out onto. The traffic seemed to go on all night, but I'm used to that at home and hey, it's the city that never sleeps :-) You may ask for a room on the 76st St side, in stead of Amsterdam Av.
There was absolutely no noise in the Amsterdam Inn itself, which didn't surprise me once I saw the hostel. The shared rooms are so small and there's no meeting area or anything, so everyone just comes to 76st St to sleep. And eventhough we had quite a big room, we never spent more than 8 hours there :-)
I loved the area: nothing touristy like downtown, its a relatively quiet residential neighborhood. It takes 10 minutes on either the subway (B, C ,1, 2, 3) or the bus (5, 7, 10, 11, 57, 72, 79, 104) to go almost anywhere.
However, it's only two blocks from the most interesting parts of Central Park (incl. Natural History Museum), just across the park you'll find the famous Museum Mile and Madison St shopping district. Nice walk!
There are literally dozens of nice restaurants, deli's and supermarkets in crawling distance. We spent quite some time just sitting on a bench, munching on our salami rolls from the deli, sipping our coffee, looking at all the foreign nanny's taking care of their Bugaboo toddlers. No need to go to semi-hot quarters like the Meatpacking District when you've got all this. 
I'll be back here. Just make sure you book directly with Amsterdam Inn. We booked at hostels[--] and lost our 10% deposit when we booked an upgrade (private bath), which wasn't possible at hostels[--]. Amsterdam Inn wouldn't give the deposit back themselves and made us pay all over again. They said it was a new booking, we thought it wasn't (same confirmation no and all), but there was no way to pay less (which still wasn't much).

title: “Excellent location!”
text: I had read the reviews about this hotel and was curious to see how it really was. I was travelling with my 11 year old son so wanted an ensuite room. This hotel seemed to offer the best deal, especially with breakfast included. The room was absolutely fine - a double and single bed, tv, wardrobe with hangers, chest of drawers, air conditioning and very clean bathroom with good shower. It was a bit of climb (we were on the 4th floor) but nothing to complain about. Every morning we went to the local bagel shop to have our cream cheese bagels and watch the local residents going to work and school. It was great to be in a neighbourhood, away from the tourist centre (I would avoid anywhere around 42nd St like the plague!). The staff at the hotel were friendly and helpful - there was no problem about leaving our bags there on our check-out day. We hired a car for the day and the hire car centre turned out to be in the next street to the hotel! There were 2 street fairs in the neighbourhood while we were there - streets were closed and stalls set up - great for strolling, eating and buying all sorts. One block from the hotel is a regular Sunday market held in a school playground - some great stalls - well worth a visit. Central Park was 2 blocks away and the choice of restaurants is endlesss, as well as super-markets for when you want to save a bit of money. I would most definitely go back to stay here - it suited our needs perfectly and I can't say enough how great an area it is. One slight word of caution - I did see one room opposite ours which was very small with just a double bed, not much space and an internal window (we had 2 windows with views over the street) - it may be worth enquiring about rooms before finalising your booking. But I would highly recommend this hotel if you are happy with a comfy bed, clean room, good location and value for money!

title: “best place at a budget price...”
text:
i was there at the amsterdam inn hotel for 3 nights it was a very nice and pleasant stay..
 i would recoment this hotel to anyone willing to save a couple of dollars.. the service is great and reliable the crew at the amsterdam inn are very pleasant, the gentleman in the evening looks kinda scary but he is a very nice guy once you get to know him, housekeeping are very good... my room was so clean and kept well and organized they even help you with your luggage this guy looks (mean) but he is a very nice guy... i had a great time i will be coming back in to new york again i'll make sure i stay there....

title: “Great location, friendly staff, excellent value.”
text: In town for the 5 Boro Bike Tour, we chose the Amsterdam Inn for its proximity to Central Park but found that it had a lot more to offer. The rooms were clean, the beds were comfortable and the staff made us feel more than welcome. Breakfasts were complimentary at a small bagelry in the next block and more than satisfied 2 hungry cyclists. All in all, we found the Amsterdam Inn to be an excellent value and would recommend it highly to anyone planning a trip to the Big Apple.

title: “Proceed with caution!”
text:
I would say the hotel is borderline average but doesn't quite swing that far.
My partner and I stayed at this hotel from April 14 through April 22nd, when New York seemed to be going through a heat wave, which to us Englishmen seemed more akin to sub-Sahara temperatures. The problem with the heat was made worse by the fact we had no air-con, although we were assured prior to arrival we would be blessed with such. In addition, we experienced frequent bouts of an overwhelming aroma of world cuisine ranging from Italian to Asian delights. This made us somewhat nauseous at around 9.00am on most mornings. We were on the top floor (albeit at our own request), but I think this added to the smell what with the rising stench.
In respect of the staff, I do not believe they were even slightly pleasant or helpful. The staff consisted of two women who dished out dirty looks and one with such long finger nails she could barely hand you a breakfast voucher - and when she did I couldn’t help but feel she begrudged it (they don't actually tell you of this 'perk', one must seek out the information and bear the looks of distain). The third member of staff was an older grey haired man who was strange to say the least and spent his time mumbling to himself like Jack Nicholson in "One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest". 
Be aware this hotel is not equipped with elevators - it has four floors that actually equates to eight (plus the first) flight of (very steep) stairs. If you are enjoying your trip with a passive partner like me, you will need some bulging biceps and a good life insurance plan to deal with this feat. Again, don't expect help from the staff.
The room, whilst very clean, I do have a few issues. 
We paid extra for a 'Queen' sized bed. When we arrived, it looked more like a UK single. The decor, whilst basic and a trifle dated, was still pleasant. The toilet was more inviting and very clean. There was some peeling of the paintwork in the bath and we had problems with the shower door falling from the hinges once or twice. Again though, nothing a pair of bulging biceps couldn't fix so weaklings be warned. I have also developed a rash on my arms, which I cannot attribute to the bed linen directly (in fact my partner is rash free), I cannot help thinking it may have been the root cause.
The towels, although reeking of bleach, still had a number of black stains on them. I would estimate you would get 3 stainless towels out of 4. 
On our departure, we had a glimpse of one of the rooms on the first floor and it looked much nicer than ours. I don't know what kind of room they paid for nor indeed am I certain what I paid for (how can anyone be sure, really?) but I would suggest you request the first floor.
The plus points were that a maid attended everyday to replace the towels and make the bed - although we didn’t have clean sheets for 8 nights which is a little long when you consider the sweat and garlic from downstairs.
The location was great - 3 stops from Times Square and we had hardly any noise in our room from the outside but as others have said, it is New York and not New Haven!
All in all, I wouldn’t stay here again - probably because next time in New York I would prefer a different hotel for variety. Because New York is so expensive it probably isn't too bad. I do feel certain places probably play on this fact and offer accommodation on the level of which in other countries would be considered hostel or refuge like. 
My partner agrees.

title: “A very steep-staircase walkup!!”
text:
Great location, clean room, bare essentialsfor $125 and $145/night before taxes.
But - the website fails to mention that this is a walkup with horribly steep and narrow stairs. You can only stay here if you have a small carryon and you must be young and healthy! There is no lobby and you are greeted at the entrance by a flight of awful looking stairs and a bad-air smell. I love to climb stairs, but even my room on the 3rd floor felt taxing to reach.

title: “It was fine for a budget hotel”
text:
I stayed at the Amsterdam Inn with my girlfriend in Februari 2006. We knew it was going to be cheap and small, and it was. We didn't expect anything, so that we wouldn't be dissappointed. (We were on a budget)
The only thing that we didn't like was the bed. It was, well, noisy. Even turning around in our sleep would wake us up because of the screeching of the bed. Imagine when we, you know... It was almost impossible.
Besides that, everything was fine and cute. We got what we paid for.

title: “No Character! BUDGET”
text: Unless you have a few hundreds of dollars to spare on a NYC accomodations, all you get at Amsterdam Inn is a tiny, modest, no character whatsoever place to sleep. It was clean, though. The window did not open, so it was a bit stuffy and smelly. The mattress was pretty uncomfortable, bed cover was a cheap, thin 'plastic' one. And, bring your own pillow! You only get 2 (for 2 people) very old and very tired thin pillows. Also, if you drive and happen to park your car at the next door parking garage make sure to mention to the cashier that you stayed at the Amsterdam Inn to get a discount ( big deal in NYC) on parking. The staff at the hotel won't tell you that unless asked.

title: “Good for a short stay, just dont expect the Ritz”
text:
having done my research on TA, i was expecting either to love or hate this place. 
It was good. It has its downsides, but these are outweighed by its plus points. really worth considering if your in for a short stay, on a budget, and only really need a place to leave your stuff and grab a few hours sleep.
Its quite unnasuming on the outside, we nearly missed it on arrival. Entry from the street is through a door next to a bar. and you need to buzz to be let in. up a steep flight of stairs to the small reception, where the staff were generally really helpfull and friendly. Our room was on the 1st Floor, so up another flight of steep stairs. We had booked a double en-suite, and actually got a triple. not much room for hanging clothes just a small rail with 7 or 8 hangers, but enough for a long weekend's worh of clothes. the room was clean and tidy with enough room for what we needed. the bathroom was very clean and the shower was nice and powerfull. We hit lucky with the room as we were on a two week trip accross the states we had 2 large suitcases and 2 carry ons, so were able to store them on the spare bed. If we had a straight double, we may have struggled.
The heating in the room was a bit of a worry at first. we were in town when the freezing cold weather had moved in and the boiler seemed to be working over time, also the radiator had a strange widget on it that seemed to let out steam! Theres no way to regulate the heat in the room, so it was a case of opening the windows. The pipes did make a lot of noise when it was switching on/off.Also we didnt appear to have air-con. not sure if they move poortable units in in the summer, but if they dont i would imagine it can get a bit stuffy. Location is really good with bars and restaurants nearby. (the chinese Mamagoo's across the street, and the small Diner (cant remember its name) round the corner for breakfast. we used the vouchers for free bagels at the shop up the road once, but with the freezing weather, prefered to sit down to a nice warm brekkie.
I was concerned that we might not get any sleep reading all the other complaints about noise, especially with the bar downstairs (worth a visit as well), but it wasnt really a problem, we'd get back and to sleep around midnight and would be woken at about 7:30 when the neighbourhood started to come to life. 
all in all a good stay and i'd recommend again to those on a short stay and a budget.
+ Points
The Price
The Location - close to central park and the subway
The Staff
Its Clean
- Points
Its Noisy (its new york, everywheres noisy! get over it)
Heating in the rooms seems have a life of its own.
No Elevator, steep stairs.

title: “Friendly and clean, but heating and noise problems!”
text: Based on earlier reviews saying that the rooms facing Amsterdam Avenue could be noisy if you needed to open the window, I had reserved a room facing the back and I was given this. I was very happy that I had been given this tip before I reserved a room as my room was boiling hot and I was not able to adjust the temperature in my room and had to resort to keeping the window open to cool down the room. Keep in mind that this was right before the second weekend in February and it was one of the cold periods this winter. My room was freezing the next morning because the heating had been turned off at some point during the night. I had a room with my own bathroom, but the neighboring rooms seemed to be using the shared bathrooms further down the corridor. It was pretty noisy early in the night with doors opening and closing. The room and bathroom was clean and the reception staff friendly, but I doubt that I would return.

title: “Great Location and Good Value Accommodation”
text:
I enjoyed my stay in the Amsterdam Inn-it seems to have been recently refurbished and I didn’t find any evidence of anyone working in the building so I presume all the work has been done. My room was a queen ensuite and the furthest room from reception-the stairs in this building are VERY steep and there's a lot of them. They're ok if you're in any way fit but this hotel is not for the elderly, very young or unfit. The room was large enough with plenty of storage, well lit and nicely decorated. The bathroom was small but had a very large shower. It was kept immaculate during our stay. It was a bit noisy-but you’re staying ON Amsterdam Avenue and to be honest, if you are looking for peace and quiet, any hotel on the upper west side is not really the place to go! The staff were for the most part friendly. One guy went out of his way to help me send a fax and their manageress who checked me in was lovely-very friendly, efficient and helpful. One guy was a bit rude when I tried to make a local call from my room-we’d paid in cash when we arrived and apparently this meant that we weren’t to be trusted with paying for the call-I think this was just this guy though as the fax was charged to my room. Trust seems to be an issue with the Amsterdam Inn-be aware that you have to relinquish a driving licence or passport to borrow a hairdryer or iron and you have to leave the key with reception each time you go out.
Do make sure and get the breakfast voucher (again you have to ask for this every morning-lord knows what you’d do if you got them all together!) as the bagels are gorgeous and it’s only a short walk away. The Amsterdam Inn is also only a few minutes walk from the subway so it’s a great base. It’s also really close to Central Park. The neighbourhood looked very safe and make sure to buy any supplies you need in the Fairway Market behind the hotel on Broadway-it’s an experience in itself!

title: “Not styley but okay”
text: The Amsterdam Inn was a bit of a surprise as it looked far better in the photos than in real life. It was in the process of being redecorated so at various times wet paint and tradespeople clogged up the corridors. The narrow steep stairs were a shock and getting suitcases upstairs was quite an effort. We had a room at the front with a great view of the street (very entertaining), but the noise at night was overwhelming and we resorted to ear plugs in the end. The room was very small and plain, definitely no frills, with a tiny bathroom. But, it was very clean, the bed was comfortable, all amenities worked, TV, fridge, air conditioner (so the room was never too hot). The everyday housekeeping service was excellent; the desk staff were very helpful and pleasant, and the all important hairdryer was available from the front desk as was competitive and comfortable transport to the airport. The location was excellent, it's a great area, and it was also easy to reach other parts of the city. Don't forget to ask for your free breakfast vouchers (they're not advertised); the breakfast bagels are just about the best in town. If you're very clear that this hotel is not anywhere near upmarket status, but offers clean comfortable (if somewhat dated) accommodation in a good area at a reasonable (for New York city) price then you might find this hotel okay - definitely take ear plugs or ask for a back room.

title: “It was fine”
text:
We stayed in this hotel for 5 nights. I have to say it was a good deal considering the price. The location is great. Nice neighbourhood, lots of nice small restaurants and diners around. Nice breakfast place around the corner and a good pub below the hotel. Close to the Central Park and metro stations. Nice streets to walk around. Perhaps we were lucky that the renovation works and re-decoration in the hotel were just completed. Although the room was small, everything was clean and bathroom was brand new. We got the room service everyday. Friendly and helpful stuff as well. 
I have to say that I was very nerveous at the beginning as some reviews here were negative but it turned out to be allright for us. Now some down points: We stayed in the room right next to the reception desk. So it can be tricky early in the morning with phones ringing. The windows were looking at the side street and indeed the isolation was not very good. But hey, it is not a five star hotel. People were doing their bests to serve and we appreciated it. So, if you are looking for a good deal this can be your choice with its small and cosy rooms and perfect location.

title: “Cheap but not very good.”
text: We stayd in this hotel for two nights during our eight nights visit in New York. The location of this hotel was great and it was cheap. But the room was small and unplaned. The air conditioner were placed at the top of the bed, next to the pillow. We couldn't have it on during the night because we couldn't sleep becouse of the noice it made, this led to a very warm nights and a lack of sleep. The noice from the streets was as we actully sleppt on the street. Overall it´s a nice hotel if youre staying a night or two.

title: “Basic accomodation”
text: Basic walkup hostel type accomodation. Shared bathrooms were clean with door locks. We had double bed in small (4m x 2.5m) , clean, room. Sheets and towels okay, and clean. Mattress was comfortable. No deadbolt on door, but they control access from street, and at top of stairs. Steep walk-up to floors, no elevator. We ran clothes lines and hand washed clothes in room sink. We posted do-not-disturb notice, so I don't know if they clean room daily or not. Air conditioner was very noisy, but room was otherwise quiet. Looks like they do regular maintenance, and are trying to improve condition. Some staff was fairly useless, others were helpful and friendly. Location is good for museums and Central Park in safe neighborhood. One street to west are a couple of grocery markets. Lots of restaurants around. Would probably stay there again.

title: “Nice small budget hotel”
text: Stayed at the Amsterdam Inn for three nights Oct. 2004. Small rooms, ok - but after all, it's NYC! The location is great for anyone looking for something quiet (if you can call any place in NYC quiet...) and near Central Park. It's also obviously less expensive than anything comparable in Downtown (which is about 10min. by the Subway).
