The lobby/reception was under construction when we went so there were long waiting times. The staff tolerated us, to say the least; unfriendly, unsmiling. Only our bellman was a chipper, friendly fellow who chatted with us and made us feel more at home.
We had two double beds. The room had the sink outside of the bathroom, which to me doesn’t make any sense – I’d prefer washing my hands before touching any doorknobs. There was no fridge provided but there was a gap where it was supposed to go. So forget about bringing in soft drinks or beer, unless you can drink them warm.
There was something wrong with the air conditioning or the insulation – maybe because it was mid-summer and high heat or maybe because of the construction – but all our maps were curled in the morning and our caps were damp. You can bend the chips – yum.
There was no breakfast included with the room, which was disappointing to start with. But the restaurant charge $5 for a coffee (not a mug, but a cup)! $5 for a glass of orange juice. We didn’t end up eating there – we ate at a little place adjacent to the hotel.
We were out and about in NYC from early morning until night time so we didn’t spend much time in the room, thank goodness.
The only plus is the location – walkable to Times Square, Grand Central, Broadway. The subway is just a couple of steps from the hotel, and of course, taxis abound.
I hope this Westin regains the reputation of its name – when we stayed, it was no better than a Super 8. The staff should be trained on how to be courteous to guests; it may even make them feel better about their jobs. As for food, the Westin should attract their guests into their restaurant by offering breakfast or cheaper meals, rather than repel them.

title: “Not Fully Operational Yet (at least I hope its not)”
text:
My recent stay at the newly-opened Westin was a little disappointing and frustrating. I usually expect very high standards from the Westin group, but this hotel is not yet operating to those standards. 
On a positive note - the rooms are newly decorated and clean, and the hotel's location is excellent. But really that is where the positives stopped. 
From a facilities point of view - There was no business center, no bar area, no breakfast (unless you have room service - and on the one occasion we used room service the food was cold). The bathrooms are tiny, with no separate shower and the towels in our room appeared to be hand-towels rather than bath towels. The lifts broke down a few times and they were often full to the point where people on the lower floors couldn't get in during busy times. In general the hotel felt like it was too full for the number of lifts available and on a few occasions there were also long lines to get a lift in the lobby.
Service is always an area where I make allowances in the US - because it will never meet the standards set in Asia, but even with this allowance the standards were not great. Our room was not cleaned until mid-afternoon on a number of occasions and sometimes even then it was not properly cleaned. With the exception of one staff member when I checked in, nobody seemed to smile and every request felt like a 'huge' deal. 
Finally, this hotel seems to have a high number of rooms, but with such a small lobby, few lifts and lack of common space it feels full to bursting. Not quite the restful experience I've had at other Westin Hotels in the past.

title: “Very good stay”
text: Recently stayed at the newly launched Westin Grand Central (was the NY Helmsley). They are still finishing off the bar in the lobby, so checking in was a bit of a racket. As a platinum spg member, I was upgraded to a pleasant corner room. All the furnishings are new and well appointed and whilst the bathroom is small, it was clean and tidy. The location is very convenient and I would certainly recommend staying here for business or pleasure.

title: “Superb Hotel and staff”
text: My Wife and I stayed here for the New York marathon, which unfortunately was cancelled. The staff were fantastic, friendly and polite. We had to stay an extra night due to flight cancellations and were given the same room (after already checking out earlier in the day!)we were not charged a cent to stay and they couldn't do enough for us. A superb hotel with great staff, I can't understand the complaints on here, I suppose some people are just too hard to please!!

title: “Great location for business trips”
text:
I recently stayed at the Westin Grand Central and enjoyed it's proximity to mass transit. The Grand Central terminal is a great place to grab a drink, grab the subway or just pick up a snack to enjoy in your room. 
The room was average but the sheets and pillows were luxurious. The bathroom was spacious and very clean and there was a huge walk in shower. I would definitely request a higher floor - being right in 42nd street = lots of traffic noise.

title: “Great location, but beware of additional charges”
text:
I stayed at The Westin from Saturday to Monday in early November with a girlfriend. We booked a room with two double beds through Hotwire for $163 per night. 
Some of the extra charges you may incur while there:
There is no complimentary breakfast offered, but breakfast is available through room service. For a typical American breakfast (i.e. eggs and bacon, etc), they charge approximately $25 + taxes + service fee ($6) + 15% gratuity. We opted to have breakfast out instead.
Internet service is not complimentary. There is complimentary wifi available in the lobby only. If you'd like internet access in your room, they charge $14.95 per 24 hour period. This should give allow you internet access on two devices. It only worked on one device for us for some reason. We mentioned this to the concierge, but she wasn't helpful. All she said was that it is supposed to be valid for two devices and offered no further help when we told her it only worked on one device.
Parking at the hotel will cost you $60 per night. There is a private parking company (Quik Park) behind the hotel that charges $41 per night. I don't know if there are others close enough to the hotel that charge less.
This last one was a huge surprise to me. They charge $1.50 for each local call you make using the hotel phone. I expected local calls to be free of charge.
The hotel is ideally located within a (casual pace) walking distance of about 30 minutes from the Broadway / Theatre District / Times Square and other attractions. There are subway stations just around the corner or down the street. There is also a CVS pharmacy down the street that is open 24 hours. 
The room was modern and clean. Toiletries were provided. The only drawback is that we could hear sirens from police cars, ambulances, and fire trucks from our room on the 12th floor. Overall, we were very comfortable.
The concierge and front-desk staff at check-in were not very welcoming. I did not see a single smile nor detect a friendly tone. They were polite with their words, but not with their tone or demeanor. They should work on their people skills.
Mattresses and pillows were quite soft. If this is your preference, then you're in luck. If you prefer firm mattresses and pillows, then your sleep may be uncomfortable.
Overall, it was a good experience and I would recommend this hotel. Just be aware of the costs associated with certain services (ex. internet, local calls, parking, etc).

title: “Good location - Good service”
text:
Stayed at this hotel while it was being taken over by Westin. It was still the Helmsley hotel when we stayed. Hotel is well located, close walking distance to Grand central station and subway stations. The room was clean & spacious with a fantastic view of the Chrysler building. The staff were very nice & helpful. We had booked this hotel via a rewards plan and didn't pay for the room. We drove in NY city and had to park our car. Parking was very steep: $70 a day ! However when we had booked the hotel the price listed on their website was $50 so after speaking with the manager we were given the rate of $50. Their rates had gone up in the meantime but they were very nice to accomodate us. We had a small problem with our room safe and within 10 minutes of calling the front desk the repair man was in our room fixing the issue. 
The service we got while staying at this hotel was very good. We had a very pleasant experience.

title: “Getting up to speed”
text:
Stayed here a few weeks ago. They're still working out the kinks. Great location, and far enough away from the tourist craziness of Broadway to be good. 
Rooms are up to Westin standards, which is to say that the decorations are nice. It's hard to retrofit a NYC hotel to make it feel "new", but it does feel like a Westin which is what I expect as a loyal Starwood patron.
The restaurant/lounge was not open yet when we were there, although they did have a limited room service menu. 
It's a Westin in midtown Mahattan. If you go there expecting a large room it's your own fault. But it was functional and clean, and I've certainly stayed in smaller rooms in NYC.

title: “Grand Name, Not Grand Westin”
text:
As a Platinum SPG member, I hold Westin to a certain level of service. I understand NYC is recovering from Hurricane Sandy days before my arrival. But, simple, communications should be available.
Specifically asked @ Business Center before arriving, was informed by your staff via email, exact location, & would have access. Arrived to find out it is not open, currently a storage closet, can use the 'hallway' as a work location.
Your restaurant/bar is not open, SPG breakfast perk, not a perk, 8 small pieces of fruit, 3 pieces of toast and coffee, really?!
Needed a refrigerator for specific items that have to stay cold, profile indicates this requirement. Was informed NO, and none would be provided I will be changed if I take anything out of the wet-bar.
From a security point, make sure you keep the door latch on, as the maid service will knock once as the are walking into your room. They didn't wait for an answer on 3 of the days, just started walking in the room.
Needed directions to MetLife stadium, asked the front desk to leave message for Concierge service to provide me the information under my door in the morning or call me after a specific time in the morning, was informed I would have to go talk with them in the morning as they are not around 'at this time' Sorry, that is a simple request, leave them a note, a guest should be able to request a note be put in their inbox. Never got the information or call.
Recommendation, close the hotel until you are fully operational, currently not worth $415/night.

title: “Great Hotel in a time of Need”
text: This was the first hotel that i saw coming down 42nd street and 3rd Ave in my car after i was evacuated from NYU Medical Center with my wife and new born baby. While our home is in brooklyn, with all bridges and tunnels closed off, we were essentially "Trapped" in Manhattan with a newborn. With no where else to go, the Westin was there right in front of me, took the wife and baby, walked right into the chaotic busy Westin lobby and asked them for a room to seek shelter for a few hours while showing them our newborn. They acknowledged right away and gave us a room. The room was better than we expected and it felt like an actual vacation. We crashed in the comfortable beds and warm room and waited for the bridges to open.

title: “Great location, very comfortable rooms”
text: Only slept in hotel as breakfast was not part of our package and so did not dine there. Rooms/beds were very comfortable and looked great after refurb. Only down side is $17 for wifi, no way, given price of the hotel! Free in lobby, hence it is always busy.

title: “Big Improvements!”
text: Day and night compared to the old Helmsley hotel. The staff was very attentive and helpful, most of the times. Small lobby area with limited bar and restaurant but great clean rooms, gym and location! Two blks from grand Central with many types of transportation.

title: “A great new place to stay in the heart of the city”
text:
Let me preface this review by saying that the hotel just opened in October 2012 and that I stayed here during Hurricane Sandy.
As a newly opened hotel, everything was spotless and attractive. The public areas were a bit cramped, but functional. Rooms were relatively spacious, and I ended up having a great view from the 40th floor (out of 41) of Lower Manhattan, including a clean shot of the Empire State Building.
In regards to the hurricane, I have to applaud the efforts of the staff. They really handled everything expertly, and I was impressed by their hospitality. First, the hotel has its own generator, which would have come in handy should the blackout have reached 42nd. Second, they modified their services to make the best of the situation - dry cleaning was halted, as was room service, but the restaurant was converted into a buffet and housekeeping was reduced but not eliminated. Third, they went out of their way to make everyone comfortable. They turned a conference room into a movie theater for children, and they opened up the other conference rooms for people to work. The lobby was filled at all times, because neighbors who were impacted by the hurricane and blackout were allowed to shelter. Amazing job by the staff to handle customers and neighbors professionally.
PROS
- One of the newest Westin Hotels in the city, it's very modern and well decorated
- Location near Grand Central is perfect for tourists, who can walk to Times Square or hop on the subway
- Great value considering that many other hotels are priced higher and don't feature as many amenities
- Handled the hurricane like true professionals!
CONS
- Can be a little difficult getting a cab at times (but that might have been related to the hurricane during my stay)

title: “WOW”
text: I'm a New Yorker and when Sandy hit, I was without power or running water. The Westin transformed their ballroom in to a charging area for displaced NYers - I was able to go every evening and charge my cell and laptop, and even download a movie with the free wifi to watch when I got back to my apartment (after the 20 flight hike, that is). There was fresh water and plenty of seating. They even set up a mini movie theater for folks to have some entertainment. This simple act of kindness during a devastating time is extremely appreciated. I will now stay at Westins whenever possible.

title: “Generous in a Crisis”
text: My husband and I live in NY and were without power during Hurricane Sandy and discovered that the Westin was offering free Wifi, power strips to access outlets to recharge and movies to entertain kids in a couple of their conference rooms. And access to their always clean bathrooms! The hotel didn't have any vacancies but this was the next best thing. They made a very hard situation much more tolerable and we were incredibly thankful for their generosity.

title: “Fantastic Hotel”
text:
We were displaced from our apartment during hurricane Sandy and were lucky enough to get a room at the Westin. The staff was fantastic - when we checked in on Tuesday, the lobby was full of people who had arrived just having lost power and water and the staff was very upbeat, helpful and friendly. The line moved quickly and we were very soon settled into a clean room and warm shower after a long day.
We were forewarned that day that with the subway's down they were operating on a skeleton housekeeping staff. At no time would we have noticed this without being told - the rooms were spotless and service always excellent. The free wifi was a very nice touch as was the movie room showing films all day to entertain people who had not planned to be in town / out of their homes. We also took advantage of the " Westin workout gear lending program and borrowed work out clothes that we had not packed to use the gym - as did many other people we met in the gym in the matching gear. 
Throughout our time there we kept commenting on how helpful and efficient the staff were at a time that the hotel was full to the seams.
We are New Yorkers and would not hesitate to recommend the hotel to any visitors coming into town - the location is great - we walked many places from here, the room sizes very good for NYC and the staff and service excellent.
As one guest we were talking to in the meeting room that they openend for guests to work in in the after the storm said to us "they have been amazing and keep saying they are on a skeleton staff - i cant imagine anything that they havent taken care of" we couldn't agree more .

title: “Location, location, location”
text: Located two blocks from Grand Central Station, this hotel was perfect if public transportation is used to get to New York City. Newly refurbished, the hotel was beautiful. The staff treated us well, but there was something missing. Little things like a quirky elevator, room keys that didn't work and a general feeling that the staff was on edge, especially, the bellhops and doormen. Cabs were hard to come by. Overall, a good experience, but a bit pricey. Not up to Westin standards.

title: “Mother/Daughter Weekend”
text:
My mom and I had the pleasure of staying at the the Westin New York Grand Central on its inaugural weekend. While the hotel was in the middle of construction that weekend, you would have never known. We requested early check-in and the hotel was able to accommodate us. The staff was friendly and the rooms were large, bright, well equipment and newly remodeled. I'm not a coffee drinker but my room had a coffee maker with Starbucks coffee. Our room had 2 queen size beds that were very comfortable, so comfortable that you might consider purchasing the bed and bedding from a catalog in your room. In addition, the hotel had a great workout room. It was even equipped with a rowing machine. If you forget your clothes, don't worry because the Westin can lend you clothes for your workout!!! 
The location on 42nd was amazing with great shopping and food near by and within a 5 min walk to Grand Central station. We highly recommend this hotel and plan to make it our home base on our frequent trips to NYC!!

title: “Displaced after Hurricane Sandy”
text: I'd like to take a moment to tell you about 2 women who made a terrible event into one that can only be described as a blessing. I was in NYC during Hurricane Sandy as a resident of the area and thought I could weather the storm...unfortunately without power that was near impossible. After deciding to walk down 52 flights with my dog and a few items of clothing...we ventured into the aftermath to find a hotel. After being turned away 3 times in the neighborhood for lack of rooms...we found the Westin which recently converted from the Helmsley...and had little faith that we could be accommodated. Then we approached Alex...who was very kind...offered me a hot beverage, a warm demeanor and luckily for us she fell in love with my dog! After being put on a list of people waiting their turn...she continuously updated me on the estimated time for check-in...hard as it was with Marathoners also seeking refuge...she introduced me to Lily who was also a dog lover and an overall sweet woman...and reassured us we would be ok. We were given a great room...with an even better discounted rate...and were reminded about the kindness of strangers in a difficult situation. During and after our 5 day stay...both women asked if my expectations were being met...and remembered both my name as my pets as well...and made the chaos outside seem like a hug from am old friend! I will keep them in our prayers...as they kept us in their thoughts with hundreds of other guests daily. A truly wonderful experience with 2 very beautiful women!

title: “Great location..good value for money...best view ever”
text:
Stayed here on my last NYC trip, asked via email for a view of 42nd Street and hopefully the Chrysler Building.
I was not to be disappointed, 39th floor directly opposite !!! the view was th best ever and this hotel holds some cherished memories for me.
The hotel is good value for money...if you want perfection pay 1000 bucks a night and go sit on your own in the Waldorf Astoria.

title: “Nice Place- Stayed during hurricane Sandy”
text: I stayed here a couple of nights last week because I had to stay in Manhattan to be sure I could get into the office during the hurricane Sandy, my office is nearby on 42nd St. This used to be the Helmsley Hotel but got redone and became Westin just a month or so ago. The room was really nice, everything was brand new so I couldn't complain. I had the standard size room with king bed and it also had a small pull out sofa and some chairs. Room has a coffee maker with Starbucks coffee and they always had free Starbucks coffee in the lobby which was nice. Staff was very friendly and as I mentioned I stayed during Sandy and at times the lobby was filled with a lot of people who had checked out but could go no where due to airports being closed, the hotel was very accommodating of all the extra people hanging around, even bring out a lot of extra coffee in the lobby to keep everyone happy and warm. The hotel is right on 42nd st and is in a convenient location for both business and tourist travelers. Grand Central Terminal is just a block away, hence the name. Maybe a 20 minute walk to times square and access to several subways in Grand Central.

title: “The Westin Grand Central has the worst service of any hotel I have ever stayed.”
text: The Westin's website falsely advertises that their hotel near Grand Central possesses amenities and features that do not exist. Don't pay extra for a "deluxe city view" room because you will be staring out your window at one of the buildings next to the Westin New York Grand Central. And don't bother asking hotel management why you're not getting what you paid for (the "spectacular city view rooms are extra $$$$, of course). You will likely be lectured by one of the managers. Although the room was clean, the management is rude and condescending ending. Stay somewhere else!!!

title: “Impressive”
text: I was booked at this hotel by my company during Hurricane Sandy and must say that I was impressed by my stay. Check-in was fast, friendly and relaxed. My room was spacious, well-equipped and very clean. The bed was particularly comfortable. The computer room, with free computer access and wifi, was especially appreciated.On check-out, I explained that I was off to the airport unsure if my flight would operate and was told that this was no problem and that the hotel would not charge me, provided I called to cancel my reservation by the end of the afternoon. The staff that I dealt with during the chaos of Hurricane Sandy were very professional and seemed completely unfazed by the stressed visitors around them . Well done !

title: “Surprisingly great.”
text: I was never a big fan of Westins but this hotel was so terrific during the chaos of Hurricane Sandy, I'm changing my mind. The hotel was overwhelmed with displaced New Yorkers and marathoners, both groups facing uncertainty. The staff was upbeat, warm, welcoming, efficient. The room was nicely appointed and comfortable. , The hotel management bent over backwards to help everyone. I was uncertain how long I would need to stay and even though the hotel was full, I was told I could stay as long as I needed and leave when I was able. They supplied free wifi and services for families. Just great.

title: “Classy and Relaxed!”
text:
Durning hurricane Sandy the Westin was amazingly accommodating to the New Yorkers in the area. The Hotel went out of their way to welcome hurricane weary nyer's with an free Internet lounge in one of their conference rooms. They set up a plethora of electric outlets and even gave us water and access to their sparkling bathrooms. The entire hotel is sparkling clean, relaxed and welcoming. The staff is great, although they didn't have an easy job dealing with pissed New Yorkers after a hurricane, they always smile and ready to help you with anything! 
Truly a great experience compare to other snobby (and old) hotels in the area. 
Prime location and close to everything -- Thank you The Westin for a great experience!

title: “Housekeeping left much to be desired”
text:
Stayed for a promotional weekend. The location is not too central as it's in Turtle Bay. The high floor room facing north (42nd Street) has a good view of the Chrysler building and pretty quiet. Bathroom, while on the small side, quipped with an amplifying mirror, is very bright. The same goes for the room, which is a nice change from other 'trendy', aka dark, hotel rooms that we've stayed recently. 
That said, check-in was a 30-minute wait. Maybe it's one-off but the lines and wagons with luggage made for a cramped lobby. 
And housekeeping was hit or miss - one day no wash towels; the other no replenishment of toiletries. It took couple calls and over an hour to get the supply. In addition, the safe was broken - maintenance had to unlock it upon checking in, but it closed by itself quickly enough before we even put stuff in. So we informed them and decided not to use it. Hopefully they will iron out the kinks over time.

title: “Big thank you”
text: i would to highly thank not only the staff of this hotel but mainly one the reprensentatives in the front desk LILY she was very nice and polite and extremely helpful, she is the perfect example of good customer service im satisfied with my stay. her service was phenomenal feels good to have someone attend you the way she did in such a respectful manner

title: “Compassion during "Sandy" / Westin Grand Central”
text:
Staying at Westin Grand Central.. All newly re-furbished.. was Helmsley something! Nice, clean, lovely rooms. The management needs big praise here..So, Instead of using their fully powered facility to "gouge" $$ as so many NY retailers are doing, they to their credit, have opened their doors to the public, guests and non-guests, to use their WI-FI facilities and have made their meeting rooms into lounges for all needy, to rest, use bathrooms, Wi Fi etc etc.. Even showing kiddie movies to those desperate folk who have no power or supplies at home...
Once in a while does one see such decency by management in these kinds of circumstance, and they should be rewarded with great customer loyalty down the road. Nice!

title: “Good location, comfortable hotel”
text: The hotel is undergoing some renovation but we did not notice any of it during our 3 night stay. The staff we found to be friendly and helpful, we weren't rushed or hurried along. The room was very clean and smart, very comfortable huge bed and there was also a sofa, armchair, desk and chair. Bathroom was clean and not cramped. The location of this hotel is perfect for midtown as it is right near chrysler building and grand central. Easy to walk to most attractions or nearby to a subway if you want to travel on metro. Or you can ask the guys outside to get you a taxi very easily. The reason this did not get 5/5 was because as another reviewer wrote, the fridge is only big enough for the mini bar and you cannot keep anything in there because in moving the content of the mini bar you are charged so don't do this unless you want to purchase - its all automatic. Also I don't think for us the bar area generally was open as when we rang to order a vodka drink they advised ll they could do was wine or beer. Aside from these niggles the hotel is very good and we would recommend.

title: “Not coming back”
text: I had several problems at this hotel. First, they (double) charged my credit card although I paid through Expedia, and without my authorization. Second, they stated that I would get Starwood points, but I did not (you don't get points when booking through Expedia). Third, they were quite unhelpful with mini bar. They refused to add diet cokes (there was only one) and if I got them at CVS and added my own drinks, I would have to remove the existing drinks, so I would end up paying for sodas I did not drink. To clean up the mini bar would cost $25 per day.

title: “A nicely reincarnated Helmsley.”
text: The interior of this hotel is noticeably nicer than it's old badge. The Queen of Mean's place is no more. The rooms are well appointed and beds are comfortable. The lounge looked nice, but, we didn't spend any time within the actual hotel. If you can score this property at the right price, I would say, do it! The bathrooms are also very nice and of a high quality. I would definitely recommend this property if you are seeking a room in the Midtown East area.

title: “Excellent location, nice hotel”
text: Came here on honeymoon in October. Great location just a minute walk from subway station. Got a room on 31st floor overlooking the Empire State, excellent view. Had food once and it was great. Rooms were spacious and very clean and serviced daily. Friendly staff.

title: “Week at the Westin/Helmsley”
text: Our week's stay was tremendous. We were given an upgraded room as it was our anniversary.The lobby/entrance area was being renovated due to the name change from Helmsley to Westin although we weren't informed of the change and thought the cab had brought us to the wrong hotel. As such, there was no restaurant or lounge but there was a breakfast area. The room was large (for NYC) and well-appointed with a great view. The shower was quite stylish. Elevators were fast. Staff were courteous and friendly and everything we wanted was done promptly. We have been to NYC many times but this stay was the best.

title: “Wish I knew then what I know now!”
text: I was pleased to learn that I would be staying at a Westin Hotel as I have had very good experiences at Westin in other cities. However, I am extremely disappointed with my stay. I knew it would cost $60 per night for valet with no in and out service. I did not know and was not told that I would be charged an extra $10 each night because they considered my small suv "oversized." I did not receive my SPG points for any of my incidentals because the rude front staff person refused to take my membership card. The room was okay but it was disappointing that, like so many other hotels now, there was no room in the minibar to store some water as a charge would be added to our bill for anything moved in the minibar. Arrived after 11:00 pm and there was only a limited room service menu available. The concierge could not provide me any information about Brooklyn except to print out driving directions for me.

title: “Excellent One Night Stay”
text:
Aggressively fast check-in with a very friendly person at the desk (Erica). Got a corner room, which was to my liking. 
Wonderful night of sleep... not unique for Westin's. Nice bathroom- the shower was stylish.
Hotel was incredibly flexible- they let me check out almost an hour late on a 4pm checkout. Amazing
Seems like a great place to stay for business or pleasure. Central location, ideal for getting out of the city.

title: “Great hotel except for the NYC noise”
text: Stayed in the hotel for 3 nights with my husband and our two year old. Loved the hotel and the room ... we stayed on the 6th floor and had a king sized bed and a sofa bed for the baby to sleep in. The room was very large by NYC standards, very new and very clean. The hotel staff could be a little friendlier but was not bothered by that much. Everything would have been absolutely perfect and would have given the hotel a 5 star rating except that there was intermittent noise from ambulances, firetrucks, police, garbage trucks .... regular NYC noise but enough to interfere with sleep if you are not used to it. I bought earplugs and solved the problem that way.....

title: “Very good experience - nice rooms and quiet!”
text:
Got a good deal on The Westin through Hotwire and loved it from the beginning. I am a sucker for big hotels and this one fits the bill. 
Friendly staff, even very late at night, efficient check-in, retro lounge (yes, pretty roomy as well) and the rooms are very nice updated. If I can find a good deal again, I will stay here, again.

title: “Not a full review- but negative”
text:
Going to the city for a weekend... had a reservation here. I made it with some reservations (groan, sorry) knowing that the hotel had recently reopened as a Westin; sometimes it takes a property a little while to get its legs under it and running as you would expect.
Decided at the last minute to cancel and stay at (famous hotel on Central Park South) instead.
My email from Westin said I had until 6pm day of check-in, Friday, to cancel.
Went to web site at 8pm on Thursday to cancel, and the web site said I had until 6pm THURSDAY to cancel.
Called Westin 800 number to straighten it out and they said I had until 4pm Thursday to cancel.
So three different sources, three different times, and I was naturally upset by this point. Called the property directly. Hotel operator puts me through... to the central 800 number again, even though I had said I needed to talk with someone at the property about the reservation.
Called the property directly AGAIN. Was very specific and asked for the front desk. Phone rang... and rang... and rang... after 5 minutes of ringing, the operator came on and apologized- but didn't offer to take my number for a call-back. Waited another 3 or 4 minutes and finally a front desk staffer came on.
She was gracious in apologizing for the delay. Explained the situation and she went ahead and cancelled the reservation without any charge. I told her I really hoped the hotel would get their stuff together and get her some help, soon!
So that's my review. Can't say anything good/bad about the property, only that dealing with them was very frustrating, that the info they email does not match the info on the web site, and the info at the central 800 number doesn't match either of those. Appears that they are also understaffed. Will be very leery of booking into this property in the next few months.

title: “Not quite ready for prime time”
text:
Great central location, and possibly a decent hotel at some time in the future, but for now, they are not quite ready for primetime. Zero recognition of SPG Platinum status. Lots of nuisance problems - inconsistent housekeeping - no shampoo one night, no towels the next. The restaurant/lounge is not open, but they offer room service.....but there was no menu in the room. They do offer breakfast, but it was like watching the keystone cops, service was absolute chaos, with the added pleasure of a mandatory 18% gratuity. The final insult - a $50 fee for using the minibar as a refrigerator....yep the teenager put something in there, but $50? The front desk assured us there was a letter describing this fee in the room - perhaps in the same place that housekeeping put the room service menu?
It was just an irritating 3 nights here. Maybe in the future, but for now, there are lots of better choices in the area.

title: “Needs Work”
text:
While this hotel has improved since its days as the Helmsley, it has a long way to go. The rooms are among the most noisy that I have experienced in NYC. Construction and road noise can be heard throughout the night. The windows in my room literally had a gap between panels that allowed a tremendous amount of noise to enter the room
Guests should know that there is no hotel restaurant or lobby bar. While there are great options nearby, it made things difficult to have no meeting place for casual business meetings.
This may get better but for Starwood loyalists, there are better choices.

title: “Terrible service and wrong debits!”
text:
My credit card was debited wrongly two times (USD 213.52 each time) by the hotel on 14 aug 12. One of the wrong debit was corrected late aug and the other debit was only corrected recently in oct 12. I have to chase and chase for the correction. It took about two long months before the wrong debits were corrected!
In addition, it is not enough for the hotel just to refund me USD 213.52 x 2. The hotel need to refund me the loss due to difference in exchange rate, as a result of the wrong debits. The hotel should ensure that I am paid back in SGD the same amount of SGD that I am wrongly debited. 
I am wrongly debited for a total of SGD 550.36 (= SGD 275.18 x 2) but the hotel is crediting back to me only SGD 266.20 x 2 - this is not enough. The hotel need to compensate my loss (SGD 275.18 – SGD 266.29) x 2 due to exchange rate difference as a result of the wrong debits. Without the wrong debits, I would not need to suffer the exchange rate loss. I should not suffer a loss due to the hotel’s wrong debits. 
 
No doubt the exchange rate difference is due to the bank, I should not be penalised because of the hotel’s wrong debits. I have re-confirmed and confirmed with the hotel staff during my stay that I will not be charged wrongly. They re-assured me but this is what happened. I am so disappointed that this get so long to resolve and I am still not compensated to a not worse off situation. Response to email is slow and the hotel is ignoring my concern and reasoning. This is so disappointing.

title: “Lots of promise but.......”
text:
I stayed at this hotel twice in consecutive weeks, the first as they were trying to complete the restaurant/bar reno and the second while they were waiting for a City license/approval. 
The hotel has been beautifully renovated and the rooms are clean and fresh, the Westin Way!
I have a couple of complaints, though. 
First, the menu is really inadequate for a full service hotel. I place some of the blame on an unfinished kitchen but still ...... Also, the prices are really unreasonable when you consider the lack of menu choices. 
Second, my check-in lady told a fib. I requested my previous weeks room which was not available th lady said I was getting a nice quiet room with a great view - that means a handicap accessible room with he weird layout. Nice room, but no lies next time please even if they're little white lies. 
Lobby service is confusion - lots of staff milling around, including managers, and causing the entrance to feel crowded. Also, not very friendly. 
Finally, and most annoyingly, the Internet connection is atrocious especially given my experiences at other Westin's. It's criminal that they charge $15 per day for a connection that's so slow, it took me 30 minutes to download an email - I even tried it at 3 am and it was slow as molasses. 
All in all, ok for a business trip but definitely not family friendly - the Residence Inn by Bryant Park is a better choice especially with young ones.

title: “A Nice Hotel in NY”
text:
I am a frequent guest of Starwood hotels, this is my first stay at this property, which just reopened under the Westin brand, formerly a Hemsley hotel, rennovated and refurbished. 
MGMT and staff are very good to excellent, there are some minor issues that they are ironing out with staff training as respects to the Starwood ways and how Starwood treats their loyal guests. the staff are from the prior hotel. The GM -whom I met seems to be Excellent and knows what needs to be done.
Comfort - the rooms were comfortable, Westin Heavenly Beds, quiet, you can't hear anybody. The showers were a nice size.
Fitness center had plenty of equipment and space and clean.
They are rennovating a new Dinning and Bar facilities, not open yet, but soon.
There are a number of dinning and pubs near by. Also your around 5 Blocks or so from times Square.
Easy walk to many businesses and office buildings
I highly recommend this hotel.
They know what issues need to be ironed out and this MGMT Team will take care of it. Staff were friendly and helpful.

title: “Ahhh, Newly Renovated in NYC”
text:
Renovation great- I love getting into a hotel before all the traffic. Lobby keeps it's retro vibe- Hallways lovely new wallpaper and carpet- Room has brand spanking new Westin trademark heavenly bed and I was fortunate to have a corner room with Chrysler Building View! Stylish, CLEAN. It's a shower bathroom which for me is great 
Check in was easy. I think restaurants are on the way. I had a breakfast room service menu in the room but not a regular one- so late night I just thought forget it.
Location good. Staff attentive.

title: “A GOOD CHOICE”
text: Westin (formerly The Helmsley). We Stayed at the Westin on E 42nd Street for two nights in October. Really nice hotel that has been recently renovated. We enjoyed the spacious room and giant bed. It is only a few minutes’ walk to Times Square and Grand Central station, where you can connect to anyplace in the city. Good choice

title: “Good renovation and conveniently located”
text: My wife and I made a quick in-and-out trip to NYC for a Saturday event and decided to spend the previous night at the Westin. The location couldn't be better unless you intend to spend all of your time in southern Manhattan. The hotel renovation is very nice, although when we were there they hadn't opened all of the restaurants yet. Just check ahead depending on what you expect in that regard, The rooms themselves are large (and very clean due to the renovation) by NYC hotel standards. A big factor for us was the price. It was very reasonable for a mid-range hotel in Manhattan--hopefully that wasn't just a promotion rate. I would definitely stay there again provided the prices remain where they are.

title: “Doesn't seem very "Westin-y"”
text:
I'm not sure what to think after staying here for three nights with a friend. Although the switch has been made to a Westin, it doesn't seem like it's quite there yet.
I stayed with a friend in a "Deluxe" room with two double beds. The room was a good size for NYC, and was clean and comfortable. The bathroom was nice and clean as well. Nothing special, but nice. The fit and finish of the room/bathroom were a little bit lacking. Not terrible by any means, but for just completing a massive renovation on the property, there were some pretty obvious shortcuts taken (not in design or materials - in workmanship). I guess the attention to detail wasn't 100% there.
By far, my biggest complaint about the stay was the beds. I've stayed in a pretty good number of hotels over the years, and I think I slept the WORST in this one. I couldn't quite put my finger on it - but it was impossible to get a good night's sleep, and I had a sore back for six hours every day. I can sleep just about anywhere, but this was B-A-D. Westins are supposed to be known for their beds, so I didn't quite understand this. They were so bad in fact, that I canceled a scheduled stay in December and made reservations elsewhere.
Some other comments:
* The towels/washcloths looked like they were 15 years old. They were thin and rough and some had some pretty gross stains on them (I don't even want to think about what they could have been).
* The staff was all extremely nice and helpful. They were responsive and always a step ahead.
* The room also has about 25% of the outlets it should have. This was a design issue that there is really no excuse for other than not having the money or wanting to spend the money. Come on guys...it's 2012. Having to take turns charging laptops and having to charge your cell phone in the bathroom just doesn't make sense when the hotel literally JUST went through a major renovation.
* The location is awesome. Two blocks from Grand Central, almost across the street from the Chrysler Building...doesn't get much better than that (unless, of course, you don't want that).
* As usual with the higher end Starwood properties, the minibar and WiFi are insanely expensive.
Overall, I would say it was a great stay, but the incredibly bad beds were a deal-breaker for me. Unfortunately, as good as the location is (and it is REALLY good), I doubt I will be back. I really wanted to like this hotel, but being tired all day and having a sore back just isn't worth it.

title: “Nice renovation, larger than average NYC rooms”
text: Had a great weekend at new Westin Grand Central...used to be Helmsley (most cab drivers know it as Helmsley.) Room and furnishings were nice and very clean. Bathroom had new vanity and tile but old tub. Staff very nice, in our experience. Only complaint was checking out late (at 1) only had 2 people at front desk so line was long. Didn't have enough doormen either, so cab line was well behaved when he chaperoned us. But when he had to leave to help unload arriving car, all hell broke loose among the guests skipping the line to jump in ahead. Not the doorman's fault. And it was a very tough weekend for cabs. Hotel restaurant not open yet. But, b'fast in lounge area was fine. Housekeeping staff was also very accommodating with extra towels and such. A great weekend all around!

title: “Scratchy sheets, hard bed, sleepless night”
text:
For a new hotel this is shameful--at one time the Westin's were known for their 'heavenly beds' but this new property seems to have opted for the lowest possible quality. I stay in a lot of hotels (so far this year, 84 in Starwood Properties alone) and recognize there is a range of quality. What i don't understand is why they opted for the lowest quality in a new property.
Other signs of lower quality: I called the front desk upon my arrival in the room as there was no internet (it said i the room had not yet been checked into). it took three calls and 15 minutes with me finally pressing the Operator to locate someone to help, (is there lack of adequate staffing even with the hotel being new?), the creamer in the room is powdered--not even mini moos, there is no option for very high speed internet, and no phone on the desk. The phone by the bed is remote, but no speaker ability on the handset, so to participate in web conferencing with two-way audio one needs to hold the handset. Further, they do not appear to have upgraded the sound proofing, i stay in NYC a lot and know street noise can be muffled.

title: “Westout”
text: Where do I start? Guess the beginning. I arrived during the rain and the doormen finally got to me after about 2-3 minutes and asked if I was checking in. They told be they don't valet and that I had to find parking structure. They provided little to no help and when I asked the concierge, she pointed around the corner and didn't offer to help by calling. Thirty minutes later I returned after finding a place around the corner. Pt 2: The maids left a vacuum cleaner outside my room for a day--just ghetto. Pt 3: A maid knocked on my door and without waiting for a response, entered. I was shocked and reported to management. Lastly, this hotel was far from being ready to accommodate guess to the Westin standard. The staff ranged from very inexperienced to very experienced and other than the great gym, there were not amenities . I really paid much too much for what I got. I won't go back to that location again.

title: “Great people, great hotel”
text:
All around wonderful experience, things I LOVED about this hotel & my stay:
- Front desk staff was so kind, welcoming (Doris or Deloris, I think) and very excited about the renovations.
- Room was GORGEOUS with an incredible view of the Chrysler Building.
- Bed was fantastically comfortable. Usually hotel pillows deflate once you lay your head down, not these. Fluffy and firm.
- Room service was 24 hours and pretty delicious. I suspect they will broaden their menu once their restaurant opens. The Room Service staff was so sweet and friendly.
The best part of the hotel was the people: The general vibe was pure happiness and desire to express superb customer service (they did!). They all seemed really proud of the hotel and just pleased to be a part of it. You could feel their excitement & it made for a really awesome stay:)

title: “Comfortable and in a good location”
text: This was my first stay at this recently converted Westin. It used to be a the Helmsley Mid Town. It has been renovated (though the lobby renovations continue. The hotel was very crowded and always a line of people at the front desk. With the exception of the house maids I never got the feeling of being welcome at this hotel. Every employee was always in a hurry. The room was very comfortable with a not so nice view and dirty windows, was next to the elevator banks and you could hear the noise all night. The room was not soundproofed very well for hallway noise either.

title: “Good location but has to raise it's game”
text:
We checked into the Westin Grand Central on the first day of its re-branded incarnation.
The check it was fast enough but we got to our rooms to find both key cards failed to open the door (not what you're hoping for after a 24 hour journey). This was quickly resolved though and we were compensated with free internet for the duration of our stay by the lovely lady on reception.
The rooms where fine, with standard amenities and a view of the Chrysler building from our room along 42nd St.
The rooms also have the bonus of having an iron and board in the cupboard.
The shower curtains are the wrong size for the bath though, so be prepared for a wet floor.
The entrance to the hotel does have a lot of building work at the moment and I presume the screened off area was being converted into a bar or restaurant. We couldn't hear the noise from our room on the 22nd floor though which was a bonus.
We checked out after six nights and again this wasn't straightforward as the billing system was down and the confused lady (not the same as the one that checked us in) went to get help and left us hanging at the desk. She came back after a few minutes and said as we're pre-paid we could leave without a check out.
Our folio was emailed to us later and the bill was correct.
Now, we chose the Westin at the last moment due to availability and price, around $500 including tax per night but there are better options in the area at the same price if you book ahead.
Would we come back to this hotel again, probably not.

title: “Try somewhere else”
text:
I travel a lot and stay at a lot of hotels. I recently stayed at the Westin in Melbourne, Australia, and was so impressed that when I had a choice of hotels in New York I naturally choose the Westin. I believe there are two primary aspects that define a hotel experience. The first is the comfort of the room and the second, the service.
This hotel has only just re-opened and so the rooms are nice and fresh, tastefully decorated and quite cosy. The bed is comfortable, the curtains block-out, the aircon works well and the bathroom is a reasonable size. I never like showers over the bath and I like them even less when the drainage does not work effectively. I mean seriously in a newly renovated hotel I do not expect to end my shower standing in 2 inches of water. Other than the shower, which was a big disappointment, the room is comfortable.
The service however was the most disappoint aspect of this hotel. There are lot's of staff but they all seem to be busy with something other than their customers. There was more than one occasion I sought out assistance only to be handed off to someone else that was even less interested. I will come to New York again in another month, I will not stay at this hotel.

title: “Great location; Hotel will be great Business Hotel after renovations”
text:
Stayed at the Westin this week, on 10/3 ... just two days after the change over from Helmsley to Westin. I am very excited to have a new Starwood property in this neighborhood, as it is very convenient to my office, to Grand Central and to many of the major mid-town business restaurants. It will be very convenient.
The hotel is still under a lot of work, so be prepared for noise. The rooms have been updated and were very nice, although a bit small even by New York standards: perfect for business where you won't spend a lot of time in the room, but not really something I would book for a vacation or weekend get-away. I was a little disappointed to hear so much noise from the hallways at night, assuiming that updated noise control would have been a part of the renovation. It was not bad enough that I would not stay here again, but generally have me the feeling that I was not really in a very private location. (I found myself wispering on the phone as I had concern that people in the hallway and the rooms next door could hear every word of my conversation.)
Overall, as a business hotel in this neighborhood, it's a great choice. Much newer than the tired Grand Hyatt and with so much construction, I can only assume that great things are planned for this property. I only hope the build out a nice rooftop bar like the Grand Hyatt has, as their location makes for a perfect place for such a bar. (If they don't however, and you still choose to stay here, be sure to go to the Grand Hyatt rfooftaop bar, it's spectacular.)

title: “The Westin fit the Bill for our Needs”
text:
We stayed at the new Westin (formerly the Helmsley) for 5 days the end of Sept. We used our Starwood points and got the 5th night free which was a great deal. The location was great. The UN was in session (down the street) so there were police and secret service everywhere. It made it rather interesting. The lobby and entrance were in disarray due to the conversion to the Westin which happened during our stay. The important thing for us is the bed is very comfortable and I that there be a bathtub. The bathtub was small- a shower bathtub combo which you usually don't get in higher end hotels, but it was doable. There is a Starbucks down the street where my husband would go to bring back lattes which was nice. We love to walk everywhere so walking a few blocks to Grand Central was not a problem. We did not see the gym nor did we need any service, so I cant speak to those issues. 
We thought the new Westin was perfect for our needs and we will stay there again our next trip to NY.

title: “Typical Westin - Location Not Great”
text: Westin just remodeled this old Helmsley hotel so everything is fresh and it all works...but there's nothing special about it. Ear-splitting techo-pop greets you in the bland beige lobby upon check-in - maybe the Westin wants to be a hip, groovy W? The rooms are contemporary, neutral and masculine with the usual great beds and nice showers, although my husband commented that someone who doesn't shave must have designed the bathroom lighting. Wi-fi is $14.99/day. They do have coffeemakers. The mini-bar has a scolding message on top that if you open it to store your own food in the fridge, you'll be charged. Plastic cups and lack of newspapers are a turn-off in something at this price point, as is the location. "Grand Central" is a misnomer. The station is a hike across three long blocks and there's nothing much in the neighborhood unless you're doing business at Pfizer across the street. At least there's a nice coffee/breakfast takeaway place next door. We ended up taking a lot of taxis because the subway was such a hassle (and at other hotels, I like taking the subway). As of October 4th there was no restaurant or bar - this wouldn't be a problem but this is a neighborhood devoid of bars and eateries unless you hike down to Grand Central Station. The facade is also still under construction. I'm a Platinum Starwood Preferred Guest but do prefer Kimptons now because of the free wi-fi, rooms with personality and style, newspapers, free morning coffee and afternoon wine. Why do cheap places such as Comfort Suites give free breakfast, wi-fi, fridges and coffeemakers while the "five-stars" fail to meet their customer's needs? Go figure....

title: “Not Ready for Primetime”
text:
The hotel's public spaces are still under significant construction. No open restaurant, no open bar, no hotel shop. Lot's of fencing and construction workers. Staff at check-in did not acknowledge the incomplete condition of the hotel.
The rooms have been upgraded to Westin standards; however, from the hotel front up to room door, there's not much to enjoy and the staff isn't making it better. I am a frequent SPG guest and I would pass on this property.

title: “Not Ready Now -- and Perhaps Not Ever”
text:
Just as the old Helmsley re-opened as a Westin, after renovation and re-branding, I have just stayed four nights, and will not do so again any time soon. The physical work is not yet completed, but the many short-comings are those of attitude and scope of service, which are not likely to be solved.
For starters, the "Grand Central" designation is a stretch, as is the haul with luggage the three long cross-town blocks from the address, between Second and Third Avenues.
Staff help was decent, including a very helpful concierge who arranged for some document printing.
But the overall attitude is cheap and cheesy -- including plastic cups in the bathroom, a pile of USA Today by the elevators instead of Times or Wall Street at the door, no service guide in the room, a key card dysfunction that forced me back down to the desk for a re-load, and one day when my room was not serviced at all.
Worse, from the perspective of a business traveler, is the annoying approach that everything is charged extra: $21 for a "continental breakfast," when there are numerous Starbucks just around each corner; a "business center" that charges by the hour for computer access; $ 14.95 per day for WiFi; and a truly obnoxious mini-bar that would bill electronically if anything was even moved. 
In short, human touch has been sacrificed for a nickel-and-dime attitude.
The old joke about New York is that it would be a great city, "if they ever finish it." As for the Westin Grand Central, even if it gets finished, it will be far less than great.

title: “Still in transition, but hoping for better next time”
text: I'm a big SPG fan and usually stay at the W Union Square when I come to NY. I stayed at the Westin to try it out as it's literally next door to my company's NY HQ. Unfortunately, it still needs a lot of work. While the staff was helpful and the rooms were comfortable enough, the adjacent plumbing sounds from showers and toilets flushing was unbearable. At midnight I was still dealing with a ton of ambient noise. Also, as a gold member, the room did not seem like an upgrade and I was told that what i was given was all they had. I know the hotel is still in transition and I will try it again in the hopes of having a better experience, but for now, I'm disappointed.

title: “Great hotel in excellent location”
text: This hotel has just changed to the Westin from the Helmsley Hotel. It is very clean and the bedding and room is very comfortable. It is located close to many interesting sites. I left on October 1st which I believe was the day of their grand opening or change to the Westin. The scaffolding was removed from the front of the hotel and the opening appeared to be right on schedule. The hotel is within walking distance to Times Square, the UN, Grand Central Station and is very close to the subway. I have stayed in NYC many times and this is my favourite hotel and location.

title: “Outstanding”
text:
This hotel is superb an oasis in the middle of busy NYC. Spent 4 nights here with my partner for my 50th. Bedrooms excellent, like a country house, wooden floors, very comfy bed, great bathroom. It's not cheap but worth it for a treat. Locanda Verda restaurant was great if portions a bit small - they also cater for the hotel and breakfast was out of this world. Spa and swimming area superb. Bar & lounge superb and so relaxing you won't want to leave.
Only small criticism was staff are very young and someone "old school" is missing at reception. It's too casual for such a pricey hotel and they were unsure of location of recommendations around the corner. 
A very small gripe though - it's a great hotel.

title: “stylish (and expensive!) hotel”
text:
After some indecision over this rating, I am giving this hotel 4 stars, even though it is outstanding in so many ways, because ultimately there are just enough issues that prevent me from conferring that 5th star. Chief among them,quite simply, is price; this is by far the most expensive hotel room I have ever taken in NYC - $700 a night before all the taxes - for a room that was smaller than what I get for several hundred dollars less at my usual hotel, and with a bathroom that doesn't compare by any measure. The bathroom was probably the most disappointing aspect of the room (and we did NOT take the lowest level of room - we had the Superior Greenwich room). 
But we wanted to stay in this part of town for this trip, and the Greenwich certainly seemed to promise the most charismatic and exclusive ambiance from among the choices. And on that score it definitely delivers - the public spaces are just gorgeous, and when it's cold they keep the fire roaring in the library all day. We didn't get to use the outdoor patio because of the cold, but in a warmer season, that is going to be a great place to start the day! And breakfast would definitely be more convenient and comfortable out there, as it is set up with actual tables and chairs. Instead, we had to take our breakfast in the library where you eat from the low sofa tables, which are perfect for drinks and snacks, but much more difficult and uncomfortable when having to eat with a fork and knife from a plate. But there is quite possibly no more lovely, inviting spot in New York to relax with a drink - it is beautifully and interestingly decorated, with subdued lighting and deep plush leather sofas that you can really sink into.....and that is precisely what makes it less comfortable, and even awkward, for eating breakfast. And there simply aren't enough spots available for having your breakfast on many mornings, and you'll have to wait for a place to free up. I think this is a serious issue that this hotel must address somehow. However, while you might wish you could be at a proper dining table while you eat it, you will not be disappointed with the breakfast as it is terrific, whatever you order. 
We found the rooms charmingly eclectic, but not exactly posh, if that is what you like. They had lots of extras, like plenty of interesting books, and of course all those free treats, which are fun and not your average mini-bar fare. (And they re-stock what you eat!) Our room on the 5th floor was really quiet, and no city noises intruded at all,even though we had a street-side room (as opposed to courtyard). It is just altogether a quieter part of town, particularly during the nights. We liked the hardwood floors, with the throw rugs scattered about, and the furnishings were inviting and comfortable. The fairly small bathroom - with only a shower and a single sink - in no way can be considered luxury. We are used to much more opulent bathrooms, particularly at this price point, but in other ways it is up to 5-star standards with plush and plentiful towels, bath robes, slippers, and great toiletries. The free wifi is something other hotels in the luxury category should be offering, and I commend the Greenwich on this.
We loved staying here, don't get me wrong; the hotel is full of character and incredibly elegant, and it excels at creating a boutique environment. However, when I think about what I could get for $700 a night elsewhere, I'm not sure I would stay here again. If you can afford the splurge, or can get a better deal than I was able to, you will love the atmosphere of the hotel, and if money is no object, then go for a higher category of room that comes with a soaking tub and more square footage.

title: “Great hotel, great location, great staff”
text:
We stayed at this hotel for our first few nights in New York. On arriving at the hotel the reception staff were fabulous, they were welcoming, knowledgeable and went the extra mile without being asked. The room we stayed in was quite small, but decked out very nicely- the only way to describe The Greenwich would be funky bohemian. The little extras in the room stood out nicely-the complimentary non-alcoholic minibar, the different linen styles/colours each day. The bed was okay, the bathroom not brilliant-no exhaust system, no shower curtain/screen so water flowed into the bathroom every time we showered.
The best extra was when you place a wake up call, 10-15 minutes after the call is received coffee and tea is delivered to the room-loved it.
The biggest issue we had was no tea/coffee facilities in the room, this was apparent in all hotels we stayed at in the US-bit of a money grab I think.
Whilst we had a lovely stay, would we stay again-I don't know, and was it worth the money per might-I dont think so.
I would however recommend the hotel as it is worth a stay at.

title: “Great library bar and a wonderful Japanese spa”
text:
I came here to have a massage after a friend highly recommended it to me. I liked the idea of a Japanese escape in TriBeCa, so I booked a "Healing Birch" massage to soothe a lingering back injury. The spa is underground, in a two-story complex that takes you away from the pace and noises of the city and into a Japanese relaxation haven. The decor is minimalistic, comprised mostly of wooden features. The bathroom is ultra-modern (they even have toilets with built-in bidets). There is a pool, showers, and steam rooms at your disposal, to use either before or after a treatment. 
I loved every moment of my massage. The masseuse used scented oils with aromatherapeutic and inflammation reducing properties. Heating packs were also applied to the sore areas de-contract muscles in order to have a deeper, and more effective massage. 
The one annoyance I had was that the hotel reserves certain spa services, and usually the more affordable/basic ones, to hotel guests only. 
While I was getting my massage underground, my husband brought a book to the hotel library bar. There was a wood-burning fire, antique rugs, and comfortable leather chairs and sofas. He ordered a single shot of bulleit, which the bartender generously poured (almost two shots). During his hour at the bar, he saw three a-list celebrities, and was treated as one of them by the very accommodating hotel staff. There is even an adjacent courtyard where smoking is permitted.

title: “Great service and atmosphere”
text: We visited this hotel in November and were immediately pleased with service. The unique interiors were comfortable and the spa was excellent. On a spontaneous note, we went to a nearby restaurant called Cuba and found it to be a great find, rolling cigars in the corner!

title: “The absolute best hotel”
text:
We stayed at the Greenwich last year just before the Christmas season and we are happily returning to do the same again.
It is a star studded hotel and yet very low key and elegant. It is, by far, my favorite hotel in the world. 
Robert Deniro has done a great job to make it feel comfortable and yet classy. The staff are very accommodating. The bedrooms are beauitiful with very comfortable beds and fun delicious stacks of old fashioned candy and snacks.
Can't wait to return !!!!

title: “Truly great hotel”
text:
We stayed recently at the Greenwich and had a wonderful relaxing 5 days. From the reception staff through to the Spa and pool , everybody was extremely helpfull. We've stayed in many 5Star hotels in both New York as well as internationally , however this hotel rates very highly.Situated in Tribecca it is handily placed for Soho/Ground Zero etc and surrounding areas so if you need to be in Times Square/Central Park etc, either travel by the nearby Subway or Taxi it.
Relaxation is prime at the Greenwich, so after a days shopping, sightseeing etc make sure you use the Pool and Spa.
Will definately return.

title: “Hurricane Home”
text:
I stayed at the Greenwich during Hurricane Sandy and on many levels all I can say is WOW.
I spend two weeks a month travelling and am fortunate to have stayed in some stunning hotels, what is unique about the Greenwich is the soul of the place and its staff, it is quiet, understated, cool yet entirely unpretentious we have all stayed in cool hotels where you go to be seen. The Greenwich is a cool hotel where you go to be yourself and relax with phenomenal staff and attention to detail. During the Storm the general manager was on hand at all times, friendly, calm and measured, the staff dealt with the situation with out losing a step. Eventually we lost power so the following day the hotel found me a hotel with power on 56th, I enjoyed my stay so much at the Greenwich I would have happily continued to stay without power. The rooms are good, the food is good but the staff and the management make this hotel exceptional. So please don't stay there as it is already difficult to get a room, but if you are lucky enough to stay, enjoy the best hotel in New York.

title: “I really like this hotel”
text:
This was my second time in the hotel.
En bref, everything that had to do with the hotel was great. What we had a problem with was the breakfast service from the restaurant.
Reception was very accomodating and efficient. They had no problems with us changing the reservation in the last minute to avoid Sandy
Guys at the door - great help with family luggage
Rooms are not only nice, and well designed, but cool and cozy. 
Also, no issue with family of four staying in a deluxe room (some other hotels would force you into two rooms, or a suite)
Bar at night is hapenning, and service is very good. 
My issue with the restaurant is that we have asked for some special dietary requirments for breakfast. It was not there, which apparently was fault of the reception. But the tone in which it was communicated to us by a waitress was condesending and unhelpful. Even my 8 year od daughter noticed tat. Then they mixed up the whole order, comign back twice with things we did not order. Butter was not brought in even after 3rd request. And I can go on and on...Now, I know restaurant is not part of the hotel, but it is a part of the hotel experience, and that even kids notice that people are rude and unhelpful really stands out.

title: “Luxury and crisis management”
text:
This hotel lived up to expectations. If you stay in New York, you can spend your money two ways - on a non-descript luxury hotel in midtown (faux luxury that is designed to show wealth), or you can find a bespoke hotel like The Greenwich. The shared spaces, the rooms, the service, the attention to small detail, all suggest real thought and care about experience. You genuinely feel special when visiting. Not just because of cloying over-friendly service either. Rooms feel like individual apartments. Bathrooms are beautiful but have function inherent - deep baths, the most powerful shower ever! Complimentary snacks and soft drinks (no petty charges). Food from the restaurant available in the hotel, rather than separately. It was wonderful.
The hotel is amazing and what is more, they looked after us before, during and after Hurricane Sandy in Oct/Nov 2012. Sadly, when the power went out on lower Manhattan we had to leave, but the concierge staff organised a room for us uptown. 
A huge thank you to the staff who were brilliantly helpful, despite needing their own food, water and heat in this time of crisis. They showed us what good service really means.

title: “What a beautiful hotel. Gorgeous room, excellent service and beautiful amenities”
text: My Mum and I stayed here, as well as a couple of other high-end hotels and I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this hotel. The decor is beautiful, the room itself was gorgeous and spacious, and the bathroom (and bath products) to die for. Breakfast in the stunning courtyard is something everyone should experience (even if you are not staying in the hotel). You can't believe you are in the middle of NYC. I can still taste the toast with ricotta and burnt orange jam! Staff are so lovely. Lots of great restaurants in the area (including next door) and a Whole Foods and giant Barnes & Noble just down the street. It is in a relatively quiet neighbourhood (Tribeca) ie lots of great restaurants, a park with a growers market on the weekend, but shopping district and closest subway a 10-15 minute walk away (the only slight negative, if you want to be in the thick of the action). But I really, really, loved this place

title: “Utterly enchanting”
text: Five nights and I am hooked. Relaxed and inviting, this hotel will charm and impress even the most seasoned traveller. We stayed in a deluxe king room and it was spacious, with a spectacular bathroom and deep soaker tub. Couldn't hear a peep from the neighbours thanks to the sound-proof construction. Meals in the lounge area were delicious (for breakfast do not hesitate - get the French toast!) The gym is well equipped, and the change room has a fabulous steam shower you must try. The spa is very relaxing and I enjoyed a massage by a very capable and attentive masseuse. The remarkably soft kimonos had me thinking I should wear one all the time. The restaurant at the hotel - Locanda Verde - is very good and extremely popular. Staff are friendly and discreet. I simply can't wait to go back - it honestly took me days to come down from what was an amazing experience.

title: “Perfect”
text: If you can, this is the place to stay in New York (even as a treat to break up a longer stay). Spent 3 nights here at the end of 2 weeks, and what a glorious way to end our holiday. Everything is just right. Not glitzy, not snobby, just so comfortable and cool that it is the best hotel we have ever stayed in. The pool is amazing (so calming) and the staff so attentive, friendly, and very interested that we were looked after just right. We stayed in a courtyard room (on a recommendation from someone else) and it was like we were in an italian city! The rooms are so quiet that we didn't hear anyone else (except in the hallway when late night revellers returned - but not once they were in their room). Loved the minibar treats (not your standard fare). Actually glad I hadn't read too many reviews or some of the other surprises would have then been expected and not exciting. Highly, highly recommend.

title: “Wedding Weekend”
text:
We spent three nights here over our wedding weekend. We live less then 30 miles from the city, but decided to stay in the city over the weekend. The staff was beyond helpful and nice. They had champagne waiting upon our arrival, accepted all of deliveries for the wedding. The spa was very relaxing. We did not use the pool, but it was great looking. The hotel bar and courtyard and tucke away and very private. The day we got married (NYC Courthouse), the hotel offered us the hotel car which was great. 
We also brought our dog (he is a very big Rhodesian Ridgeback) and every time we took him for a walk he was greeted with treats and open doors! 
The location is awesome. It is in TriBeCa and a short walk you have views of the Statue of Liberty, a long walking path and a great selection of places to eat and grab a drink.
The restaurant attached, Locanda Verde, is amazing. We had our wedding dinner there. 
This hotel is first class and is a true gem in the city.

title: “The Perfect New York Hotel!”
text:
Without doubt this is one of the best places to stay in New York. We stayed here for our honeymoon and the location is excellent. If the retailer Anthropologie did hotels this would be it. What a wonderful place!
The rooms here are spacious and beautifully decorated. The beds are very comfortable. The feather pillows were too soft for our liking and the hotel swapped them immediately for firm foam ones and they were much better. They then made a note so we were sure to have the same for our next visit. Rooms have a complimentary mini bar (alcohol not included) and a snack basket. A fantastic touch and very useful after a long day out and about, especially if you like Hershey's Peanut Butter Cups! The bathrooms are perfect and all the usual touches you would expect. Very large shower, water in all directions. Toiletries excellent. Beautiful handmade soaps.
In our opinion the hotel website doesn't quite do the hotel public areas justice. There is a private sitting room with bar for hotel guests only and here you can order inspired cocktails and delicious food from the adjoining restaurant whilst sat next to the crackling log fire. Free hotel wifi, fast connection. Beyond the private room is a wonderful courtyard garden where you can eat and drink alfresco. There is also a large public sitting area at the front of the hotel. All in all plenty of room to relax after a long day walking in Manhattan. The Robert De Niro art on the walls is a lovely touch. Good actor, hotelier, restaurateur AND artist!
The restaurant connected to the hotel, Locanda Verde (accessed through hotel or separate street entrance) is excellent and serves delicious Italian inspired food and drink. Warning: it gets very busy most of the time and booking a table is recommended. Breakfast here is also very good but as already described you can order from the menu in the private sitting room if you prefer. The hotel also has an excellent room service menu for ordering in your room or downstairs.
The spa in this hotel is truly magical and the swimming pool well worth a visit. The 250 year old structure that surrounds the pool is totally original and an inspired touch.
The service is outstanding, friendly and nothing is too much trouble.
Just one criticism: the bathrooms can be a bit noisy in next door rooms. For us it was not a problem as we rose very early due to jet lag. This is a very small problem and all in all the positives made this insignificant to us.
The rooms prices indicate the level of attention to detail and service. You will not be disappointed. Well worth a visit!

title: “Glorious”
text: Stayed here on the first night of our honeymoon, on our way out of the country. Absolute perfection - from the fabulous staff to the serene pool to the delightful basket of goodies, handwritten note and warm cookies awaiting us in our room. (Ryan Reynolds in the elevator didn't hurt, either.) We plan to come back here every year... And we've already recommended it to friends who were equally pleased.

title: “Sophisticated and Relaxed Boutique Hotel”
text: We enjoyed the location of this hotel, with a very city feeling, yet fresh, sophisticated and upscale. The personel and service at the front desk during check in was very helpful in making dinner reservations and getting tickets for a Broadway show at the last minute on our last night on the East Coast. We liked our room with a bath, large and spacious, and especially the afternoon light in the bedroom. All the extra amenities were a surprise. The bar area was relaxed and comfortable, and a little dark for us. The Italian Restaurant had a stylish design and the food was delicious. The dining area with its bar seemed very popular. We asked for a table away from the bar, which was quieter and we enjoyed looking out the window at the city view. The staff at the entrance were very welcoming and helpful. Enjoyed the boutique size and more intimate feel of the hotel.

title: “Respite in the middle of busy city.”
text: Just stayed at Greenwich hotel for a 3 night girls weekend. We arrived early on a Thursday thinking we wouldn't be able to check in but luckily our rooms were ready. The smell of the hotel was heavenly and the 1st thought that came to mind was homey and cozy. The lounge and courtyard were beautiful. I liked our room but it was much smaller than what I expected and the bathroom was crazy small. I booked what I thought was a larger room (superior) but was disappointed. The bed was AMAZING! The towels on the other hand scratchy and stiff. My major complaint actually happened before I even arrived.
